reviewText:
I have about 600 linear feet of shelving held up by various sizes of Fast-Mount brackets.  I first discovered them at Home Depot but they discontinued them after about a year.  My shelving projects take a long time to build and I often change the configuration.  I refused to switch to a non-supported shelf bracket system and found that Amazon carries many of the Fast-Mount products (all except the 6' wall brackets).  The price was on par with Home Depot and I didn't need to drive 70 miles to pick them up - plus, no sales tax!  I ordered about 6 dozen shelf brackets of various sizes and more 4' wall brackets than I think I'll ever need.

I have most often used the 2' deep shelf brackets spaced at 32" centers mounted on the 6' wall brackets.  Along one 16 foot wall of my garage, I store more than 2000 pounds of lumber (on 5 levels) with no hint of strain.  One note of caution:  I anchored the wall brackets into the studs using 6"x 5/16" lag bolts because I knew I would have a huge load on them.  This is way beyond the normal 3"x 3/16" screws that I use most places.  The secret to the strength is the angled supports under the shelf bracket.

I called the John Sterling Company, maker of the Fast Mount system and inquired about the size differences between the shelf and wall brackets purchased from Home Depot a year earlier and those from Amazon.  The Amazon shelf brackets were about an inch shorter and the wall brackets were about a quarter inch smaller (mounts closer to the wall).  They explained that the cost of steel had risen so much that instead of charging more for their products, they chose to cut down on the sizes a little without compromising the load rating.  They are apparently correct.  I find no difference in performance and the older products are compatible for the most part with the new ones.

Shipments of these rather heavy items came in very small packages, often one wall bracket at a time.  Each one of 40 brackets was carefully wrapped and labeled individually.  Except for disposing of the huge cardboard pile after unwrapping, it was  LOTS easier than going to Home Depot.  I just hope Amazon will continue to carry Fast-Mount products for many years to come so I can supply my next shelf project.

I just bought this to replace an identical one. The first one failed 3 years and 3 months after the date stamp (of manufacture), probably after about 2 and a half years of service. I have a good, clean, city water supply. The second one failed after 1 year and 11 months. These are too expensive -- I'm not doing this again. I whipped up a substitute from parts from the local plumbing store for $16. (See photo) I put a manual valve in the middle to regulate the circulation. With the valve cracked open just a bit, I get the same results (same water temperatures) as with the Grundfos when it was new.  If you have space under your sink and are handy with tools, give it a try.

The Grundfos is a thermostatic valve. When it is working properly and your circulating pump is running, the water at the sink where this is installed will be warm (not hot). It will be the same temperature on both hot and cold faucets, at least until you let them run for a while.

Mine failed in the open state. The symptom was that water at the sink was HOT on both taps, and the shower was much hotter than usual. This was while the pump is running.

My second one failed closed. If it fails in the closed position, you will be back to the original state before you installed this, with cold water from both taps, until you let the hot water run for a while.

I wasn't sure about this because of some of the reviews.  I think often reviews come from the extremes, either someone really really likes something or they really hate it and want everyone to know.

I read reviews stating the the sole isn't square to the side, and I found this to also be true.  I have engineers squares that are supposed to be square to .00063" or 16 micrometers, so I believe I can measure for squareness.  I could see a sliver of light under the toe of the square, but I don't know how much that really is.  Consider the sole is only 3/4" wide, so a sliver could barely be a fraction of a degree.

I tested the plane, right out of the box, by clamping a guide board on top of a piece of mahogany and started forming a rabbet with the grain.  I trimmed a tenon shoulder and out of curiosity, planed the edge of a piece of plywood.  I got decent results each time with no sharpening from me.

The feel of it is kind of sharp in the hand.  They could have relieved the edges a little more, and I think I will except where the sole meets the sides.

All in all, it's not bad for the price I paid and it suits my purposes.  Amazon says that the normal price is about $130.  I paid about $65.  If it weren't on "sale", I'd buy from one of the other brands, such as Wood River or maybe even Lie Nielsen.
summary: A good deal depending on the price.  Not for the tool purist.

This works well for me and is very simple to use.

The detection area is very wide and makes it much faster to pinpoint the rough location of studs in the wall.

Only complaint would be that the display method is inherently a little imprecise and you have to make a bit of a guess as to exactly where the edges of the stud may be. However; if you're trying to find the center, or near enough, then it works perfectly.

If I was to buy another I'd probably look for something a little more upscale that can more precisely tell me where the edges are for when I'm trying to cut holes in the wall, and maybe something that can tell me the material that's being detected, but this sensor does a great job at quickly finding the obstructions.
summary: Works well and fairly idiot proof.

The many poor reviews and complaints about this socket not being able to make contact electrically with a candelabra socket are likely because the user hasn't yet removed the cardboard liner wrapped around the outside of the medium base socket.

I opened the package and imediately took a pair of scissors to snip the cardboard wrapper, then peeled it away from the metal socket. Not only does it seem a potential fire hazard to have a paper product in direct contact with a potentially hot light bulb base, it looks like crap compared to the shiny metal medium base socket hidden beneath it!

This metal socket adapter works perfectly for me. After removing said cardboard, it screws into the candelabra socket fully, and is more compact than similar plastic items sold by other manufacturers...

If you insist upon having something covering the outside of this medium base socket before you install it in your chandelier, I guess white vinyl electrical tape would do the trick...

That cardboard is probably intended to protect the metal socket from damage during shipment.

reviewText:
Ordered it Saturday July 22nd and it was delivered the next Friday the 28th.  No issues with the delivery or packaging, everything came thru perfect.  Using a bobcat with forks, we moved the pallet into the shed.  Once the plywood crate came off, you can use the lift bars (which each slides out to 10 3/8 inches and  4 5/8 inches when closed) in the tool to use a forklift to move it off of the pallet.  The bobcat had movable forks to slide in tight to the machine and come under the lifting bars.  I preferred this over straps hanging the machine from the forks.  I built a mobile base from 3/4 plywood, and 4 inch casters positioned under the corners of the tool, with a weight capacity of 850 lbs.  Uncrated the machine weights 753 lbs.  The planer has a hollow base with an open bottom.  This machine has the new updated decals and paint job from Jet.  The older jet tools the last several years has a "yellow-white" paint.  The new upgraded tools have a bright white paint which matches the new updated longer bed Jet 8 Inch HH jointer I bought recently.  Not all of their older models that they still sell have the updated paint color.

It does have a short 10 awg cord 5 foot long.  You can swap out the cord with SOOW ( sometimes called SO) 10-3 AWG cord that you can buy at Menards for $35 for 25 feet.  With SOOW cord they count all 3 wires so you need 10-3 cord (black, white, green).  I am using 10 gauge wire in the wall to a 30 amp breaker.  I have yet to use it as I am assembling and will update the review when used.  At this point the fit and finish is perfect and I am somewhat OCD :)

The Dewalt DW788 is my first scroll saw. Haven't even used someone else's before. So I would really like to thank everyone who took the time to write a review on it and the other scroll saws at amazon. It was the primary reason I chose the Dewalt.

I make boxe's, all kinds, shapes and size's. I have pretty much quit using metal fastener's, hinges, knobs, catch's, etc. I really enjoy making my own out of wood. Have been using a multitude of power and hand tools to make my own, but thought a scroll saw would allow me to make even smaller, more intricate pieces.

Assembly was very quick and easy. I added rubber feet to the base of the saw as it will sit on a workbench not on its own stand. Have a small shop, every thing has to be mobile. I also purchased a foot switch as everyone I talked with about scroll saws seems to feel it is a necessary safety feature. With a combination of the rubber feet and a rubber pad, the machine doesn't move at all, even on speed 8. Vibration is very minimal, and luckily the saw is at the perfect heighth when sitting on the bench. The dust blower works adequately, but I am going to rig a vacuum source up somehow. Changing blades is a bit of a challenge at first, but I think with time and practice it will become much easier. I also have rigged a swing arm lamp to use with the saw, old tired eyes ya know, need all the help I can get.

I mostly use hardwoods, and thickness's up to 1" so blade selection and speed are going to be critical items. So far I probably have spent 10-15 hours just practicing, using differant woods, blades, speeds, feed rate, etc., and taking a few notes to help later on. I am very happy with the results so far. Have made two sets of decorative hinges out of mesquite and am very pleased with the small kerf I was able to achieve and how well they fit and function. They took a bit of time to produce, but I know that will change as I become more practiced and comfortable with the machine's ability and of course my own.

I spent a lot of time researching scroll saw's before purchasing the Dewalt. It will not be used everyday, but hopefully will be used a lot for a long time. So I wanted a machine that would last a long time and I believe the Dewalt will do the job for me.

One of the first things I noticed about the Samic cree was the fact that it comes with a rechargeable 18650 Li-on rechargeable battery. Another bonus is that I don't have to purchase and extra charger because I can simply flip open the silicone port on the side , plug in the flat USB cable and the included AC adapter into a wall receptacle. I do love flat cables, but one of the most interesting things was that the cable has a Lighting end, a micro USB, and USB ends. I absolutely love the versatility of this cable and have never seen anything quite like it. Each end is covered to keep the crud out. This Samic cree is a small, but very powerful LED tactical flashlight that's perfect for camping, generalized household use, or to put in that emergency kit. The lighting is so much more powerful than that of an old-fashioned flashlight and since I've been using this type of flashlight, I've never looked back. It will light up an entire room and, as many in this size group, can be seen for almost 200 yards outside. It's not touted as being waterproof, but certainly must have an IPX4 rating or higher, making it water-resistant. It comes with a convenient case and wrist lanyard with a metal swivel quick-release snap. FEATURES: CREE XML L2 1198 Lumens Ultra Brightness. Best Gear For Camping, Travel, Outdoor Activities and Home Emegency Rechargeable 18650 Battery and Adaptor Included Micro USB and USB Port Which Can Charge iPhone 5/5S/6/Plus And Android/Window Phone (Charging Cable Included) High-Quality Aviation Aluminum Alloy Materials. IPX-7 Waterproof Stands Up Securely On A Flat Surface To Serve As Candle A single charge varies, depending on the mode you are using. There are five modes: Low / Medium / High / 10HZ Strobe / S.O.S. There are three simple blue LED indicators that give me an idea as to how much charge I have left. This cree will last approximately 50,000 hours, a real plus. I'm not quite sure how long the battery itself will last, but they can be replaced. The silicone control button is a light action one, making it easy to use. A long press will shut it off rapidly. The bright black anodized aluminum casing is quite solid and definitely tactical in nature. I can place it on one of its ribbed sides and it won't roll and I can also place it on end. If need be, it could be an excellent emergency beacon. This is an excellent handheld flashlight that would be an excellent one to add to that emergency kit. It's easy to operate and with those different modes, a very versatile one. I do like the LED lights and the longevity factor. There won't be any replacing the cree because it will last for 50,000 hours. I don't know how many times I've had to search around for a small replacement bulb for my old-fashioned ones (which aren't any more water-resistant than this one). Sample provided for review.
summary: A high-quality, 5-mode flashlight that's a perfect addition to any emergency kit ...

reviewText:
I had to repair the drywall on my ceiling due to leaking toilet upstairs. The hole was less than 1 square foot.
When it came time to texture the surface the choices were use a machine to blow the spackling which is overkill or
use the Homax spray can which from various reviews on Amazon is a hit or miss proposition and messy.
One Homax reviewer recommended the Pirate Patch and looking at their website it looked easy enough so I brought one.  It's pretty pricey but compared to a can of Homax it wasn't that much more.

The results I got was awesome with no mess of a spray.  Believe the pictures on the Pirate Patch website.  My results were exactly the same except it was on a ceiling done without gravity assist.

The material used is high quality metal and not some plastic.  The thickness is just right and the metal putty knife I used slides easily over the metal template.  Only thing I would do to improve the product is for the metal to be black instead of silver so there can be more contrast between the template and the spackling.  But I guess anodizing it black would add to the cost of the product.

Some tips from my experience.

1) Practice on a piece of scrap drywall or cardboard to convince yourself how easy this is.
2) I would consider taping at least one corner for an anchor point.
3) Scrape off all excess spackling so that the spackling in the holes is flush with the thickness of the template.  This process is like spreading peanut butter thin except there is no bread to flake on you.  No need to knockdown if you scrape off excess.  I tried knocking down and the results are not as good vs if I didn't.
4) Clean off the bottom surface of the template between applications as the excess spackling accumulates
5) To avoid lines at the edge of the template when stepping across different sections of the drywall have a little overlap and don't press down too hard over the section you already worked on.
6) Make sure you clean the template immediately after you are done so the holes don't clog up.  Process is like scraping off the peanut butter.  Rinse with water.  It does take a while to get the spackling out of the tiny holes in the template.

If you got a larger area to do then I would recommend spraying with a machine unless you have a lot of patience to do this half square foot at a time.  But for small repair jobs Pirate Patch is perfect.
summary: If you can make a peanut butter jelly sandwich this is easier.

reviewText:
I paid more for Bussmann (bought 1 package each, ATC and ATM) because I assumed (you know what they say about assume?) it would be of better quality than some of the much larger packs of fuses, and it came with a puller, with tester.  In the long rung I paid about 2-3 times what I could have and had the same quality but much higher quantity of fuses and paid less for a cheap little puller.

As some reviews have said, the fuses in the kit(s) can not be tested in spite of coming with a tester that has instructions for testing.  The fuses are the cheaper fuses, that although have the test ports (holes in the top) the probes can not reach the metal contacts, even if they were small enough in diameter to actually reach all the way in.

I'm sure the fuses themselves will work fine but for the cost and hype over a nearly worthless tester, there are better options.  Oh, and the clamsell package which would make it easier to keep them secure, is secured to where it's nearly impossible to open without damage enough to keep it from closing well enough.  I didn't expect a "case" but a package that would be good enough to use to store them.

I did have a fuse to replace so I checked and found very few fuses in that car that could even be tested.  Most mini's do not have test ports and the puller is nearly if not completely ineffective in pulling them because of size.  It works well pulling and installing the standard size fuses though.  For half the money I would have bought a variety package of both sizes, got a cheap $1 puller and some kind of cheap bag or case and put that in the vehicles for storage.  I'm disappointed in Bussmann which has been a name I've been familiar with for years and years.  I might expect something like this being dumped on Woot, but not retailed on Amazon.

1 positive I can say, the fuses do have the amp stamped on the top for those that aren't familiar with the color codes.
summary: They work but....I'm disappointed in Bussmann

reviewText: Best work light. I am a professional mechanic and my income is directly proportional to my ability to see things. Most work lights last a month. This thing has lasted years. Super tough, can grip anything, and point anywhere. This is my go to light. I love this light. The first one was yellow, left in a trunk and never seen again, lasted 18 months. This one is black to not show dirt and I love it.

For the price, it doesn't get much better. These really were just popped out of a CNC machine, had the hardware stuck in them, and shipped out. No frills here. Click it on, it's on bright, depress button partially once for low intensity mode, another time for strobe, and another time to go back to bright. I don't think you really can complain about such a cheap flashlight that puts out so much power from one AA. If it lasts a couple of months, I will be more than happy. Will update with any problems.

Edit 5/2015: So I've been using this thing daily for quite some time now, and I just recently realized an easy fix to this light's only problem: the lid requires almost constant tightening. Just poor machining I guess, there is metal dust in the threads when you use it. Anyways, just put a piece of foil around 1/8 inch thick above the spring in the body of the light. It'll keep the battery in contact so you don't need to constantly tighten the light.

Despite the constant need for adjustment without modification, it's a great light for the price. The battery life is surprisingly good as well. I've changed my battery twice in the entire time I've owned it, if I recall correctly. As I mentioned, I use it daily.

This is a medium duty hammer tacker that handles 3/8 inch staples with ease. I used it to staple grade D building paper to wooden studs, and after a few swings I figured out just how much effort I had to put into the swing so that the staples would bury themselves. It weighs just under five pounds empty, and that is the proper weight for the job. The handle is well contoured and textured for my hand, which is small for a man. My wife has very small hands, and found this tool to be too large and heavy for her, but she doesnt share my love of tools

I have arthritis in all my joints, and this tool did not bother me in any way. After tacking up the paper, I went over the staples with a hammer, to make sure they were all buried. It took very little time, since most of them were fine. It was an unnecessary step, but my OCD took over.
The tool is well made, of quality materials, and feels solid in my hand. The staples load easily, and it did not jam once during my single day use. I would rate this as a solid and reliable hammer tacker.

Most similar saws has a frame that holds the blade from the point of the end of your hand to the end of the frame. This hacksaws holds the blade from under the palm. on the one hand is leave less place to grip, but in the other hand, it shorten the frame, so this saw can be seat very nice in a 22" tool box/bag, comparing to my old hacksaws, that must be taken in hand and it was very comfortable to store and to carry. I've bought 4 or 5 0f this model in the last 20 years for my business.  They feel like the big grinders, and will cut as well if you use the fast-cut wheels.  The first thing I do when I buy it is throw away the guard.  They have new dangers with the guard plus are not near as versatile.  The nice thing is if you get hung up you can handle the torque better than the full size grinders which I feel makes them safer.

 where do they eventually fail
1  brushes wear down,  you can order new brushes.  do it before they start arcing bad
2 gear head goes bad,  not if you re-pack it with grease before it starts growling
2 cord separates in side,  you can only hang up dragging the chord around the shop so long before this happens.  I re-wire from the switch to the plug with  silicone shielded drop chord.
3  cutting wheel shaft gets bent,  if you lay it on the floor it can't get jerked off the bench by your foot.  They are fairly easy to bend.  if not bent too bad your grinding wheel will wear until straight.

I have all my old ones in a box to pick-a-part.  so far I've used a switch, and a couple arbor shafts.
the next grinder I buy will be another 9005B

On Friday I received by Schlage deadbolt. After installation when I tested it I found that I wasn't able to lock it by pressing the Schlage button. I've gone through the troubleshooting steps, disabled / enabled the Turn Lock feature, and reinstalled many times. Finally I think this should be a defective one. Schlage asks customers not to return to the retailer, but their customer service was not available until Monday, so I asked Amazon for a replacement, and Amazon was able to deliver my replacement on Sunday - even before Schlage customer service's next business hour. I'm not sure how Schlage would handle this case, like how soon would they ship a replacement out, whether they'll ship a replacement before receiving my old one, whether they'll cover the two-way shipment costs, or whether they'll agree to ship me a replacement at all. So today I received my replacement from Amazon. After installing it I tested to make sure that the locking feature is working. However I found that it was able to be unlocked by simply pressing the Schlage button. Again I went through troubleshooting steps, reinstalled many times, nothing helps.

By comparing the in-door part of the two deadbolts, I figured out that the first one is missing the cam. Without the cam the deadbolt would think itself being in locked status forever and refuse to engage the extractor when pressing the Schlage button. I have yet found the issue with the second deadbolt but it could only be that either the signal wire is broken or that the switch failed to close when the deadbolt is locked.

Should I ask for another replacement? I guess not. This is a serious security product but it was made like a cheap toy. Now both units are packed and waiting to be dropped at UPS, and Schlage customer service has yet entered business hour. But that doesn't matter anymore because this has been a brand I'll never going to consider.
summary: Two defective units in a row - untrusted brand

I absolutely love this product! One canister of propane lasts forever. There were two main reasons I bought this. One was to burn leaves and debris that accumulate on pond rocks used in our landscaping. Over time, stuff accumulates on the rocks and between them. The rocks kind of get buried unless you move the rocks, clean up, and then put them back. No more. The leaves, debris, etc. turns into ash and just washes down to the soil with the next rain. The torch is also handy to burn weeds that come up between the rocks.  The torch will burn nutsedge to the ground, but will not kill it. It will start growing again the next day.

The other reason I purchased the torch was to light my charcoal. I put the charcoal in a charcoal chimney, light the torch, and hold it on the charcoal for about 30 seconds. I no longer need to use a newspaper, lighter fluid etc.

One other note, the Bernzomatic website still lists the JT850 as a product in its line. It does not say it has been discontinued.
Only used a few times so far . It works great . I will recommend anybody needing this get it .
summary: It works great. I will recommend anybody needing this get it

High quality receptacle. Just what I needed to create a 50' welder extension cord from a dryer outlet. Some other reviewers were concerned with possible durability issues with the plastic cover. I think you'd have to be pretty careless to break it, such as throwing the outlet across the shop floor or just throwing the whole cord on the floor. I've used it for nearly 40 hrs worth of work in my garage and have not caused any damage. If you're a field welder looking to make an extension using this and will be throwing it in the back of your truck and on the ground in the field, then just buy a real extension with molded ends for 5X what I've got in my garage welder extension cord.

The only negative is that the backing plate had some sharp edges that I broke with a file. It is a high-production stamped part, so it's understandable. Just be mindful to take care of it if you will be handling the receptacle frequently.

Yes, these locks are much better than the similar looking Master Lock knockoff. Sesamee has been making these locks for much longer, and Master Lock is making a cheaper version based on the distinctive look that Sesamee has always used for these. Along with being more rugged and longer lasting, the Sesamee lock tumblers also stop on the '0' when rotated backwards. This is a critical feature if you ever have to open a combination lock like this in the dark. You can roll all of the dials back to '0', then count the 'clicks' as each tumbler increments forward - all without the aid of a light source. Try doing that with a Master Lock! The Master Lock tumblers don't even 'click' as the turn.
summary: Sesamee is better than Master Lock

It's nice to have a normal door bell now.  The 40+ year old door bell buzzer that was original with the house we moved into 9 years ago, was just that, a buzzer.  It sounded horrible, and would wake the dead, when someone rang the doorbell.

This one lets us know someone is there, but is not loud or disturbing enough to wake our 4 year old son from a nap.

Also, the installation could not have been simpler.  I just took the old buzzer down, marked, drilled, and hammered level drywall screw receivers into the wall, connected the old wires to this door bell, and screwed it up.  I think the whole process took me 15 - 20 minutes.

Good weight for its diminutive size -- you know you've got a tool in your hand.  Great for a variety of jobs.  It's a great size (small/compact) and power (bright white) to keep in the glove box.  We often use flashlights when out on walks at night, and would never want to use the BRIGHT setting for fear it would "light blind" oncoming drivers, bikers or hikers.  But while out at night, it's nice to have the option to really light things up!

One draw-back is that the HIGH setting always comes on first; if you want the low beam, you have to reset it to LOW from the initial HIGH light.  That can be a slight nuisance.  Would like more switch options to turn on at HIGH or LOW, constant, pressure switch only, and a flashing beacon setting.

This tool is classic Chinese.  Cheap and poorly made.  Why did I buy it?  I didn't know if I would use a spoke shave and this was a good way to find out without a big investment.  I found I do like the tool's concept but out of the box it is a disaster.  It took about two hours plus to get it satisfactory.  First I had to sharpen the chisel.  After working it with grits from #200 to #600 I honed it on a leather strap.  It is now ok.  The next thing you have to do is work on the contact surface.  It was taken out of the forge, painted, assembled and put in a box.  The base is no where close to flat.  Working it with a variety of files and then various grits of paper and finally polishing with rouge and a buffing pad (Dremel)  I got a nice flat polished base.  After all that the tool works fairly well.  If I find a lot of uses for it, I will buy a good American or German made shave.  If you don't want to do all this, spend some money and buy a good one.

reviewText:
First, this fan works great. Even on high it's relatively quiet where you hear just the wind. On low, you hardly notice it yet you can still feel the cool breeze. But as things go there are issues.

If this is the first fan for the room that you are installing it in chances are you are replacing a light fixture. Problem is this is just a fan so you won't get your light back. The description didn't say without light and every fan I've ever seen in any home had a light. But don't assume they all come with one - this one does NOT.

Easy installation is relative to the situation. And I doubt most DIY installers actually confirm there is enough support to hang this. You can't just replace the light fixture, you need to make sure there is something solid to bolt this to. I had to crawl up into the attic and install a 2x4. Overall it took me a good afternoon to complete the project.

This ceiling fan is not expensive for a ceiling fan and the quality indicates that. Right off the first step to installing this the holes didn't line up for two brackets. I had to do a little bending to make it work. Then it calls for an 11/32 wrench - why 11/32? Do they actually save money on such an odd size? But the nuts were actually 9/32 which means they were too small. Fortunately, this wasn't required to support the fan. The screws to drive into the 2x4 to hold the fan were cheap and rounded off and I couldn't completely tighten them. Fortunately I could get them out and replaced them with quality screws. Other screws requiring a philips driver weren't deep enough to get a decent grip to tighten but with patience and care I eventually got it done. There is an included weight for the chain extension but nothing to hold it on to the chain. I decided it was too long anyway and didn't use the extension.

One step I added was try to hang the fan housing to see exactly how low it would hang and found I preferred the shortest tube. Which does make it a little tighter space to do the wiring.

It looks like a fan, nothing stylish about it, the main housing looks like a spaceship. But we didn't expect it to be a centerpiece... It doesn't look bad just looks like a fan.

One feature is that it is designed for outside use like for a porch. Obviously, not directly in the rain but it's supposed to be waterproof against moisture.

Overall, once the installation was complete it works great and we will appreciate it on the hot days. It also can be set to reverse to spread the heat out during winter which we will have to test later. But now we have to figure out a new light...
summary: Works great and is relatively quiet but a few issues

For the money it is a bargain, and I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a low-cost, high-quality router.  It fit my budget, and I am going to enjoy owning it.

Install took me a whole 5 minutes, with a new sink. Only needed a standard/straight screwdriver and plumbers putty. Unlike the EZ-Mount you do use plumbers putty with this mount on a steel sink.
Looks good quality but returned for other reasons!

Installed this under our kitchen sink. We have a tankless hot water heater and it took forever to get hot water to our kitchen faucet. Installed this inline with the hot water line. Now we have enough hot water to wash pots and pans. Went with the 4 gallon model, rather than the smaller one. For our particular installation space was tight but we changed the sink flange to a lower profile model, coupled with a tight 90 degree elbow on the drain gave enough room to slide the unit under the sink piping. We had a 20 amp circuit to plug this into and so far the breaker has not tripped. We are very happy with this setup.

This is the third WIFI controlled thermostat I've installed in the last three or four years.  I started out with a 3M one that had worked fine, but apparently they had so many people on their network that changing the system temp from a phone, webpage, or iPad took over 10 minutes to actually update my thermostat.  I got tired of that delay, did some searching, and picked the Ecobee over the Nest.  I've been using my Ecobee for the last 7 months or so, and love it.  When this came up on the Vine program, I almost passed since I had JUST installed the Ecobee recently, and didn't want to go through the hassle of changing out.  But the voice control intrigued me, since I have a lot of things in my house controlled either by voice or by wireless.

The installation was actually incredibly easy becuase of my Ecobee.  Since that has a control board that I wired into the furnace, all I really needed to do was pull the wires from that to the thermostat, and connect them directly to the furnace.  That way I still had all the Ecobee stuff connected in case I wanted to revert.  My total install time took about 5 minutes.  I didn't screw the thermostat to my wall, I'm waiting for my final decision before taking that last step.

White, Green, Red, Yellow, and the constant power C wire were all that's needed.  The connection is a simple push connection, with the wires held in by the gripping of the connector.  There are no set screws.  However, there's not much room for wire under the thermostat, so make sure you're wires will be able to be pushed back into the wall if needed, since unlike some other Honeywell thermostats, there's not a lot of space here to bend wires over.

Once it was connected and I returned power to the furnace, the thermostat lit up and offered the setup options.  Language, then type of furnace (high efficiency or below 90% efficiency), type of heat source (gas/oil, etc).  How many stages.  Once past that, it offered to set up the schedule now or wait.  I remember another reviewer mentioning how easy setup was at the screen, so I tried it.  And that reviewer was spot on.  This screen programming was about the easiest I've ever done for any thermostat, screen or PC / Web setup.  You can pick days that will bunch together on the same schedule, then set wake, leave, return, and sleep times, and temps for all.  Fan circulation also has a schedule it can follow the same way.  I actually like that part better than the Ecobee since there was no way to NOT circulate during some part of the schedule.  This way I can have the fan not turn on at night, for example, if it wakes up my 10 year old to hear the fan cycling on and off several times an hour.  However, with the Ecobee I could specify how much time each hour it circulated, down to as little as 5 minutes.  That way I could tweak it for more or less fan runtime keeping the house freshened.  Back to the schedule setup, I only needed two schedules, the days I work (M,T,TH,FR) and the days I don't (W,S,SU).  That was quick and easy since you just push the days involved in the current programming "group" that will use the same settings and times.

The final step on the thermostat gives you the webpage, MAC address, and PIN for the thermostat.  Open that on a computer, tablet, whatever (I used my iPad mini) and create an account, give it the MAC of the thermostat and the pin, and it's linked.  It was that simple.  I then downloaded their IOS app to my iPad and iPhone, and once I gave that the account I created (email address and password used to link back to the mothership) it was online as well.

Most thermometers can vary up to +- 1 to 2 degrees.  My 3M thermostat, between it's variance and the wall clock/thermometer on the wall above it, I had 3 degrees of difference.  The Ecobee had about 1 degree difference.  This one split the difference, and it showed about 2 degrees more than the thermometer above it.  But after 15 or so minutes of my setting everything up, getting the iPad and my Surface pro linked, it settled into the same temp as the thermometer above it.  This is a first for me.

I'm only about 8 to 10 feet from it when I sit on the couch, and it's very easy to read.  You can set the inactive brightness level as well, which I like since after my son goes to bed, the lights are off in the great room while I do remote client work from my couch.  This way it's not just turned off, I can still read it.  It displays the indoor temp and humidity, but the temp is the largest number, easy to see.  What can be more difficult from farther away is the outdoor temp and humidity as well as the indoor humidity.  The current "Set to" temp font is about twice as large as the outdoor font, so it's easier to read from a distance.

There is a "Smart Response" setting which I like, that learns the time needed to go to various temps, so when you set it to be say, 65 at 7 AM, it'll turn on sooner so that it hits the target at the time you want, rather than start from wherever it is at that time to try to reach the temperature you desired.

The color options are nice - I've never had one that let me change the "theme" of the display.  You're generally stuck with what they want you to see.  The Ecobee had a nice screen as its default, multi color and better than the 3M one was, but this one is actually more useful for me.  Larger temp numbers easier to see from a distance.  I'm not a fan of white backgrounds on things like this, so for me it's more visually appealing than the Ecobee as well.

You can also select 12/24 hour clock, which for me is a biggie since I am a veteran, and prefer a 24 hour clock.

You can override the default "4 changes per day" setting and select only 2 if you wish.

For business use, there's a "preoccupancy purge" option that will get fresh air going before the beginning of the day.  Not needed for me since I leave the fan in circulate mode, so it cycles the fan throughout the day anyway to keep air fresh.

However, that's the downside of this unit.  One reason I picked the Ecobee last summer was becuase I have a whole house dehumidifier unit (HRV) and the current Ecobee, while not able yet to do advanced things with it (although they say that's in their development timeline) can at least cycle it on and off with the furnace, so I know I'm pushing stale air out and bringing in fresh air - which is especially important this time of year, when we've spent so many days with our highs being below zero that the house never gets opened up at all.  With this thermostat, I'd still have to deal with doing things manually.

I was disappointed in the Honeywell website - I wanted to find a PDF with the voice command options, but they don't even have the manual available.  When you go to the support site to the "Find My Manual" section, and type in this part number, there are zero hits.

There is supposed to be a voice command card in the box, but I can't find one.  And without the commands listed on teh website so far, its a bit frustrating.  I finally found one on wifithermostat.com though.

So you can say "I'm cold/warm" and it adjusts one degree.  You can specify "Make it 5 degrees warmer/cooler."  Or "I'm very warm/cold."  But things I would've thought obvious you can't, such as "Turn the fan on."  And for some reason it seems to have problems with some numbers, so when you say something, it's a random chance whether it hits what you wanted or doesn't.  Or "I'm sorry, I do not understand."  I tried 20 times to get it to be exactly 60 degrees as the set point and not once did it get it right.  Trying different numbers had similar effects, getting it right less than half the time.
And oddly enough one time it said it couldn't contact the server, so it didn't even try to figure out what I said, which seems to imply that the voice function will fail if it's not used on an internet connection.  The straight out thermostat touch screen will, but apparently not even the voice command side of things, which for me was unexpected, I had assumed that was built into the unit.

As far as internet response times (which was why I replaced the original 3M I had), this one is quick like the Ecobee.  I set the desired temp with my iPad, and in about 6 seconds my thermostat updated and the furnace turned on.  I changed the setting on the thermostat itself, and it was about 4 seconds for my computer to see the update on the webpage.  I was pleased with the quick update time.

I love the display.  It's the nicest one out there, and I may keep this simply for that reason, at least until Ecobee can do more advanced controls with an HRV unit.  But for the price, I don't see how this is worth that much more than a standard WIFI thermostat simply becuase you can use voice.  It's actually faster to use your phone / iPad / computer than it is to use voice anyway, due to the delay after saying, "Hello thermostat" then waiting for it to acknowledge it, then waiting for it to get to the listening screen, then waiting for it to process the command, then waiting for it to act on it (or screw it up, and having to correct it multiple times).
summary: Love the display, but voice commands are flakey and not worth the extra cost

reviewText:
FIRST, I mean no disrespect. Here is a message I just sent to Ridgid:

I purchased a Ridgid, 18 Volt Cordless Drill-Driver, MN R86007 on July 3, 2009.  I bought and used it for homeowner level chores only, even though I am a 25 year veteran of the building industry.  Neither the tool nor the  batteries have been abused in any way.  The tool is fine.  In fact it's an EXCELLENT product!

My only problem is the batteries!

The two batteries I got with this tool stopped holding a charge about three monts ago, despite VERY light use since purchase.  I have used many, MANY different cordless tools in my professional building career, starting with Makita in 1981 (also excellent tools).  I have never, EVER experienced the kind of disappointing service from ANY cordless tool battery as I have with these. In fact, I have Makita NI-CAD batterirs that are still working after 8 years! The replacement costs for Ridgid, Lithium-Ion batteries are unbelievable -- especially since the whole LI technology will soon be upstaged!  IMHO, the cost of replacement (even at Amazon) is preposterous, because ANY battery that sells for this price should perform very well for at least three to four times longer than these.  I hope Ridgid tool users are not victims of the morally reprehensible practice of "planned obsolescence"!  I keep hearing how proud you folks are of your tools and your warranties.  I hope your policies rise above the rest of the power tool industry.

Please advise: What can I do to fix this problem?

Kind regards,
summary: Excellent performance, but not for long!

reviewText:
A bit pricey to me. Definitely a PITA to fill. I doubt I've ever filled one without letting some expletives fly. The process packs the sand in very compactly. The end result is that the bag is rock-hard and doesn't really conform to the terrain on which you're placing it. If you think you can just partially fill the bag to make it more shapeable, you're wrong - it just doesn't work that way. The result will be unusable. So you're left with a bag that's straight and hard as a rock - not ideal for its purpose. But the reason you're buying these is because you have some sort of problem to address - like a neigbor's yard that drains directly to yours and causes SEVERE flooding of your back deck and pool area!!!
Bottom line: I'm glad these are available but think improvements could be made.
summary: Buy them if you NEED them...

reviewText: I purchased these security hangers to hang some frames above our newborn crib. I have to say that we feel 100% safe as there is no way the frames will accidentally fall off the wall. (We hung them higher than the child will ever be able to reach so our goal was to ensure they could never accidentally fall, as opposed to being pulled down. However, I believe that they are secure enough to withstand even toddler tugging, but would never recommend that). The only thing i will say is that you need to be above average on the handyman chart. They isn't to much leeway when installing and you better have your numbers accurately calculated to ensure proper distancing for the anchor holes. The holes must be level as well. Overall, i would buy these security hangers again if the need arose in the future.
summary: Works as intended - securely attaches frames/art to wall.

I would give it 5 stars if it lasted more than two or three months. It did make our water and ice cubes taste better. We particularly enjoyed the fact that as ice melted, the taste of the water in the glass stayed fresh.

Every one we have bought developed a leak from between the screw-on collar and the valve body. This means that unfiltered water sprays or runs into the pitcher or glass you are using.

We first thought we might be overtightening it, so the next one was tightened only enough not to leak. It failed.

With the next one, we tried to avoid putting too much stress on it when we moved the lever. So, the next one was actually secured to the faucet spout with tape to take any stress off the attachment of the body to the faucet. It failed.

It's too bad Brita can't tell the Chinese factory to use a little better or thicker plastic to make this product stay in one piece. Chinese shortcutting has increase their profit by a nickel per unit, but has lowered durability and has already cost them sales, at least in this household.
summary: A 5 Star Product With 1 Star Durability

reviewText:
Out of the box it's a nice bright orange handle, excellent check pattern provides good grip and a large stainless clasp to secure in a pocket.  The blade opens and locks securely.  Beautiful, bright steel blade with a razor sharp edge and substantial blunt hood rather than a pointed/sharp tip.  Whistle built into handle.  Glass-breaker built into handle is operated by closing the knife and squeezing the handle.  This action causes the point of the breaker to protrude.

The heft of the blade, handle construction and grip shape/relief give the sense of a robust knife.  Whistle is loud enough to be useful to get attention.  Uncertain as to the effectiveness of the glass-breaker as the knife handle's lack of mass may impede.
OUTSTANDING
perfect

I purchased a  Moonrays 95433 in June 2013 which worked fine until it quit working in Dec. 2014; I have no idea what happened to cause it to fail. We went without yard lights for a couple of months when I purchased the Paradise GL22300 which never worked at all, right out of the box.

March 2015 I ordered the Moonrays 95433 again to see if this one will last longer than the previous one; when theses work they work well. Wish me luck! I'll update this post if necessary.

UPDATE July 2015 - The new unit I purchased in March died this week. This was my 2nd unit that failed, this one failed much quicker than the first one. The unit powers up, the display works and I can set the parameters I want, but it won't turn on the lights even if I cover the sensor. I'm going to need to find a different brand of transformer to power our yard lights (~225 watts worth). I am lowering my rating to 1 star for reliability.
summary: Great product when it works - first one only lasted ~a year and a half; 2nd one lasted ~4 months! Buyer Beware!

They're not meant for torquing applications, they're meant for light duty, as it seems some people with more negative reviews had issues with. I use mine to quickly loosen/tighten smaller bolts that I don't feel like doing a lot of ratcheting on. You could also use them on bolts that you want to secure quickly but not too tightly, and then go back with a proper torque wrench and tighten to the right torque. Wow, this thing is a piece of crap-ola. I used their cheap-o plane for years and it did OK.  Thought I'd ask for an upgrade for xmas.  I looked at the LN and this one right as it was coming out.  Thought , eh, it's Stanley.  I'm sure they wouldn't make a crap tool.  Boy was I wrong.  My wife got it for me and I excitedly sharpened it and trued the sole.  Made a few passes and boom!  The lever cap popped right off.  There's no way to properly seat the poorly cast lever cap with the set screw.  I tried so hard I broke the set screw.  They sent me a new one so I thought, maybe that's the issue.  Nope.  Same friggin problem.  I make a pass, the plane comes apart in my hands. What a joke.  PLEASE don't waste your money!  I wish I hadn't given my cheap original Stanley away. Now I'm embarrassed to ask my wife for the LN for xmas since she already got me this one and it was what I asked for.  Merry xmas to me!
summary: Can I give it a zero?!? Die cast lever cap is a JOKE!!!

reviewText: love it

I'm impressed with this bulb, much as I have been with other G7 LED bulbs. It's a very compact bulb - it's roughly 2.75 inches from base to top. A very Munchkin-size bulb, but it puts out a surprisingly ample amount of light.

I'm using it in an articulating desk lamp that I use for close-up hobby work using a magnifying stand. It replaces a compact florescent bulb rated at 23 watts. I'm far more satisfied with the LED bulb than the CF bulb. The light output is about the same between the two, but the 3-watt LED light is clearer and less yellow, making it more comfortable for viewing. Most important, there's no heat output, so I can position the bulb close to what I'm working on and not have to deal with a hot bulb.

The light output is rated at 250 lumens, so this is not something that will light up the full room. But, for close-up work, it's perfect.

The build quality is at the usual G7 standards, which is to say it is excellent. Very solid feeling. I've yet to have any problem with the durability of a G7 bulb.

This is an excellent choice for instances where you need a compact bulb. Highly recommend.

Nice when they worked, then after a few weeks to a few months would just randomly go on/off in the night. This happened to all 3.

The Orange blades are the way to go for auto paint surfaces.  Didn't leave a scratch and rigid enough to last a little while.

Apparently, those clear bras don't come off, easily.  With my fingers, I was getting a few small flakes at a time.  I'm thankful this product came with a scraper tool, since it's not very easy to hold the blade with your fingers.

Make no mistake, if your auto vinyl is being a nightmare, it's still a LOT of work, but these blades cut my work to about 3 hours vs. what would've otherwise taken me 3 weeks and 17 cases of beer.

I probably went through 5 double-sided blades to remove the clear-bra.  I have 95 blades remaining, which will sit in my tool box for an indefinite amount of time.
summary: Got the Clear Bra off my BMW

reviewText: I bought 3 of these Danzes to replace the plastic drains that came w/the new Delta faucets I'd recently purchased.  At this point, the Danze purchase appears to have been a good decision.  Plus the pricing for this unit on Amazon, relative to what I saw at HD, is/was very attractive.  I'd recommend having plumbing putty on hand to 'beef up' the gasket/drain hole seal on the bottom of the sink - which should also be used (v. silicon seal) when seating the drain 'cap'.  I found that the Rectorseal pipe dope available on Amazon, while a little messy, was very user-friendly for adding that extra bit of anti-leak 'security' to the threaded portions of the drain (v. using teflon tape).  I actually ended up using the Delta-supplied drain pop-up connector parts as the Danze pull rod was a bit snug in the pre-drilled hole in the Delta base, so it's best to not toss any parts out before completing your install.  Bottom lining: I highly recommend this pop-up drain set.

I purchased this at a big box store, wished I'd looked here first because of price.  I found it easy to install in my situation and the faucet looked and worked very nice. It performed great for about two years, then it started having a small leak at the handle.  I let it leak for a while and finally took the handle off and found that it had a replaceable cartridge that was fairly easy to replace with a genuine Kohler part.  I ordered the replacement, it cost $25.62 with S/H.  When it arrived it took less than 20 minutes to replace from turning the water off to back on.  It worked great again, I really do like this faucet, when it's working correctly.
However, six months later the replacement cartridge is leaking again, much more than the original did.  I'm not happy.
==
I've left a message with Kohler Customer Service and am awaiting their return call/email.  I'll edit this review when I get this sorted out, or a new faucet.
I would have rated it higher if I had not had this problem.
==
Edit: Kohler responded quickly and suggested my issue was with the rubber 'O' rings in the handle.
They sent me an complete rebuild kit free of charge and I did the work myself.
It was fairly easy work and when finished the leaking handle did not leak.
You just turn the water off under the sink and repair in place, no need to remove the unit from the sink.
It once again works as new.

What happens is that over time the lubricating grease mixes with dirt/grime and doesn't allow the 'O' rings to seal.
Part of my repair was thoroughly cleaning the inner brass parts of this faucet.
Then installed new 'O' rings and clips, re-lubed all with a special waterproof teflon-type grease from the repair kit.
Thanks to Kohler for the good Customer Service.

I did need to add Loc-tite Thread locker to the threads of the Allen screw in the handle to keep it snug.
summary: Nice looking faucet, but it can leak at the handle

STOP!  Before you buy this switch make absolutely sure the place you want to install it has a NEUTRAL wire.  This does not mean a "white" wire.  You will often find in older homes, your switch can have just 3 wires, load, live and ground. This will often be black, white, and green.

When you take the HS200 out of the box you will see it has FOUR wires: 2 black, 1 white, 1 green.  The 2 black wires act as live and load, and while interchangeable on the switch, you CANNOT connect both blacks from the switch to the single black wire in your box.  No matter what anyone tells you, please DO NOT try to override this configuration by wiring your TP-Link neutral (white) to a green ground wire.

This switch is decent overall, however I think TP-Link needs to do a better job of conveying this issue up front. True, they do state clearly you need a neutral wire, but frankly, how many DIYers know what that is?  They see black (or red) and white and think "live and neutral".

Now, for me I knew that I did not have the neutral wire where I initially wanted to install this switch.  But I love TP-Link WiFi outlets so I really wanted to try this. I installed it in a part of my home which is newer and has the required neutral.  The installation is just as simple as any conventional switch.  The box includes the needed wire capes and a matching wall plate.  You can use this snap on plate for a very finished look, or use your exiting "Decora" plate.  I went with the included plate as it was new, so new looking, and had no screws, etc.

Using the Kasa app on my phone it was easy to set up the switch.  The issue I ran into is the switch would not always work manually, so I don't know if it was defective.  It did function fine by schedule or Alexa commands, but if we happened to press it, sometimes it was fine and sometimes we had to hit it 4-5 times, so I think it was mechanically defective.

I give the concept a 5, the design a 3 because they do not account for the majority of homes which likely have just live/load/ground switches, and a 2 in my case because it had to go back, being defective.

.
summary: Good Brand, Limited Installation (MUST Have Nuetral Wire), Mine was Defective

I purchased this as a replacement to the burned-out S6 incandescent bulb in the ice and water dispenser in the door of my side-by-side Frigidaire refrigerator-freezer. I also bought the G7 Power Boulder LED 0.5 Watt (5W) 15 Lumen C7 Night Light Bulb, 2900K Soft White Light, E12 Base 2-Pack at the same time to compare. I tried them both, and this one is a little bit dimmer than the other, but it's not a major difference either way, and both served the purpose well. This bulb's globe is also a little bit shorter and skinnier, which made it easier to install and remove in that tight little space with my big dumb fingers. I ended up leaving the other slightly brighter and larger one in, because it didn't make much of a difference to me, and I didn't feel like swapping it back out. They were both worthy options. If I had to choose only one, I'd probably go with this one, because even though it's a little dimmer it's still plenty of light, it's a little easier to install, and it's a little bit cheaper as a single bulb instead of a 2-pack. But you can't go wrong either way. I leave the light on all the time, and unlike the old short-lived incandescent versions, I'm hoping to get a very long life out of these. Neither will do much to your electric bill, as the incandescent draws only 0.05 Amps (five one-hundredths of an Amp), but even these brighter LEDs draw only 0.004 Amps. It's really not much.
summary: Perfect for fridge ice and water dispenser

reviewText:
I purchased the Streamlight 88040 ProTAC HL High Lumen Professional Tactical Light and found it to be extremely bright. It is well constructed and seems as if it will hold up well, time will tell. One concern is that after a few minutes the front end does get very warm / hot to the touch, at this point that has not created any problems but I would be reluctant to leave the light on for extended periods of time. So if you're looking for a high-powered tactical light for short duration use, such as disorienting and intruder, this product fits the requirements.

Pros:
- solid construction
- relatively small lightweight
- extremely bright for its size

Cons:
- the head gets very warm after only a minute or two of use, this is only a concern at this point.

I would recommend this flashlight for the specific tactical use which it is designed for. After using the product for about a week I went ahead and purchased a second one.
summary: Streamlight 88040 ProTAC HL High Lumen Professional Tactical Light

This was sort of an experiment. I repair wheelchairs and other mobility devices, and have a wide variety of tools I use on a daily basis. I have one large toolbag, a Husky 20" as my main repository, but it's too bulky to carry around. I also have a smaller to-go bag, open top like the husky. It's a good little bag, but it quickly gets cluttered with other tools I tend to grab from the bigger one from time to time. I was hoping this backpack would solve the problem.

But it didn't. The number of pockets was ok, but there weren't any pockets for smaller things, like dental picks, medical clamps, precision screwdrivers, etc. Plenty of pockets for all my driver handles, wrenches, and even socket strips, but just not enough for odd-sized stuff, like my multi-meter, which fit into one of the larger flap pockets, but then the flap doesn't quite catch on the velcro. Also no good place to keep a bundle of zip ties where they're easy to get to.

The bag also wanted to flop over all the time, even though I have tools in the front and back.

But the worst thing for me, it wouldn't sit right just slinging the bag over one shoulder. That was the deal breaker. I wasn't going to be always using both straps, probably rarely (which is difficult with a jacket on).

Regrettably, this one will be returned, and my search continues.

The timing was perfect when I was offered the opportunity to review several different G7 LED bulbs. We're starting to replace the incandescent and CFL bulbs in the house. We have a variety of styles - floods, round, candle - you name it. Some on dimmers, some not. As bulbs burn out or fail, an LED takes it's place.

If you use LED's, you know the many advantages - cost less to run, are not damaged by vibration (ceiling fans!) and don't get too hot to touch.

This small globe is in a fixture on our ceiling fan, gives off an amazing amount of even light. We replaced a 70W bulb with this one, and honestly can't see a difference in the light. Brightness, color of light - looks the same as an incandescent.

LED lights have improved massively over the past couple of years. Compare an LED bulb with the same specs from several months ago with this one - this bulb is cheaper, made better and much brighter.

This light is incredibly bright - if you stare at it momentarily you'll see spots for a while. It's far brighter than an equivalent incandescent bulb, and much better quality.

This bulb is bright, cool and well made - 5W? Wow.
summary: This bulb is bright, cool and well made - 5W? Wow.

reviewText: They look and feel amazing

This is really the best combo headlamp with everything I wanted, well except color. The LED is on the cooler side of neutral, probably 5500k.  I ordered neutral white to avoid the green/blue output color which is normal with a cool white LED.  Just FYI this has a tint of green even with it being a neutral.  Youll only notice the touch of green on a wall.  Using it as I intend to do it won't show any green, its not that bad.

The battery tube is angled so don't think thats a defect.  The AA slides in just fine.

The output ramping is very quick and easy. I don't know why I thought this was unnecessary. Now Im reminded how much I couldn't stand preset levels when working in tight conditions.  There was never the right amount of light. The TH20 solves that problem completely. I won't be without this flexibility now.

The unit itself also can be adjusted up or down for good angles of light at infinite positions.

Its got Instant turbo on (with  Li-ion), instant moonlight, and a Brightness level memory, even SOS is you're a nighttime bike rider,

The dimpled orange-peel reflector does a great job of spreading that light around. I didn't want a spotlight on my forehead and this has great flood. We can attribute that to the XPL LED. My old headlamp had and XR-E and they are too narrow of a beam you're always moving your head to light something up.

All of the above is so easy to do. None of this is any amount of hard work like I expected.  Some headlamps force you to hold buttons in to turn it off and on, or they have some tiny plastic button that you almost need to press with your finger nail.  The TH20 is super easy one clock or double click and you're good!

Comes with extra o-rings and and extra rubber head plate, which seems to hold it very well and is not uncomfortable, unlike plastic ones. It also holds the lamp away from your forehead so it won't get too hot.  I have not sweated in it yet, thats a true test of a headlamps strap.

Great purchase.  Best of all, now I don't have to put my flashlight in my mouth just to have both hands free!  That was getting gross ;)

Bought these to replace rusted old hinges for the tray doors under my kitchen sink.

These were reasonably easy to install once I planned how I was going to install them. This is how i did it.

1. Installed both hinges to the cabinet frame first leaving 3/16" from the bottom of the window in the frame.
2. Removed the spring from the hinge with a pair of pliers and safety glasses on.
3. Predrilled holes for screws, tightened and removed screws once to tap the holes before final installation to make it easier. You will be screwing these at awkward angles.
4. Measured hole dimensions for the doors from the two mounted hinges.
5. Drilled and tapped (using the screw) one of the four holes i marked on the door.
6. Mounted the door using one screw to make sure everything lined up as intended then unscrewed it
7. Drilled and tapped the remaining 3 holes
8. Re-installed the springs
9. Put in screws for the trays
10. Installed the door with all four screws

The doors lined up square and level to each other within ~1/16"...hooray. If i could do it most others can too
This small project taught me the old machinist's saying "measure twice and cut once"

Took 1.5 hours in total.

Cheers

reviewText: I bought this directly from HomeSeer. While you can do much more with this than any other Z-Wave controller I've seen out there, I had to add a cron job to reboot this weekly as the HomeSeer process hangs (the Raspberry is still accessible and working fine, but the application fails).

Not the kind of item I get ecstatic about, but I like it. If you need something like this, this is a cheap & acceptable way to go.

Recently found the battery life is not as stated 100 3" screws per charge (about 60 2" screws). I noticed different motor sounds between the one bought at Amazon and at Homedepot. And the one got from Amazon seems to have less torque?! Wish I'm fine for the long run. I aslo tried the drill capability and it is fine for small job as well. Overall it is pretty good.

I first bought the RIDGID 24V version driver/Drill in a package with a reciprocating saw. After trying it, only the driver/drill serves me well. After talking with Homedepot sales, I decide to return it and get a driver set only. I ended up with this model for the sake of battery and light weight. Once I got it home. Men, this thing rocks! It charges quick and deliver lots of torque which I can't tell the differences between Bosch PS20 and RIDGID 24v for 2 inch screw, though the speed is not fast. Since changing windows won't need too much screw, it serves me very well.

I also bought a DelWalt 1/4" interchangeable tool set. It has extension with screw guide tube, all kinds of screw head, basic sets of drills and little tools to drive your wrench set. Basically it immediately turned all my hand tool to power driven!! It's a must have type of company.

I think I won't try to drill holes with it since it's RPM is only 400. So I'll use it as it is designed for.

After comparing the price, I decide to return it to Home Depot and buy from Amazon. It saved me $40(only $104.84 plus free 2 day shipping). And amazingly, after only one day, the tracking told me that my PS20 is on the way for delivery. I couldn't wait to see it at home. Amazon did a excellent job on delivery.

By the way, the one I ordered from Amazon is made in Malaysia, while the one I bought at Homedepot is made in Thailand. So it seems it is made everywhere.

It is a power DRIVER not a DRILL. Take it seriously!!

Enjoy it!
summary: A good compact driver, but beware of actural battery life

reviewText:
The one star is to get your attention.  In general, there is no doubt that Moen makes quality products.  I run a motel with 40 year old single cartridge Moen faucets.  Even though we have very hard water, the cartridges are just now being replaced.  But I bought this for a new install... willing to pay the extra price for moen quality.  I distinctly remember a slip of paper in the box that said that the cartridge did NOT need to be removed for soldering.  This seemed odd to me, but I went with it.  But after installed, the handle was very hard to turn.  I took the cartridge out and did not see any "damage", so thought that it was just the nature of the beast.  But after sitting for a week, the handle would turn at all, and when it did, it broke the adapter.  Went to the Moen website and the video says specifically to remove the cartridge before soldering.  Well, now I'm waiting for a cartridge rebuild kit and a new handle adapter.  Hopefully it will solve my problem and I won't have to replace it.

By the way, you go to the installation instructions printed and it gives NO advice one way or another about taking the cartridge out before soldering.
summary: Bad Instructions... ruined my new faucet.

reviewText: This faucet was SO easy to install.  And it looks lovely.  I like the pull out hose; although truth be told, I don't really need it.  It's just kind of a nifty novelty.  Reading other reviews, I didn't have any problems with clearance, but I can see what others are saying about putting the pull-out faucet back in the hole.  Although, I haven't installed the weight yet because I wanted to get the feel for it and see how much length I want.  The only issue I had with installation was the tight squeeze with the plastic lock-nuts.  Actually, the issue was with my sink.  Whoever cut the hole to install the sink didn't quite get the concept of oval, and put the faucet hole right up against the wood.  The lock-nuts are kind of wide at the top (almost like it's a washer and nut in one), so I didn't have enough room.  Being the middle of the night and the store was closed to find a smaller nut, I had to improvise and was able to sand down the width of the lip of the plastic-nut. (I'm happy to report, it's still holding.) And lastly, I am a bit bummed that I paid more at Home Depot in the clearance pile ($88), but that is irrelevant to the function of the faucet.  It's a good faucet, but I was skirting the high end for what I think it is worth.
I have no complaints about this product and I have no problems recommending it to others.

I will be on the lookout for the Milwaukee 3/8" Impact Ratchet #2668-22 that will be out this Fall. It will complement this 1/4" ratchet for heavy duty work...a perfect pair.

reviewText:
I bought the smaller version of this towel hook the first time and i absolutely loved it so i looked for one a lil bigger.
I Love the fact that all you have to do is clean the wall and stick this to it , no tools needed. We don't have alot of room
in our bathroom and nowhere to hang towels except over the shower stall, so these hooks worked perfect for what we need.
The hook actually has a tiny hook on the bigger part of the hook so it keeps the towels from falling off it alot better
then the small one did. Also you can hang 2 different things like the top and bottom of a wet bathing suit on it and it
doesnt fall on the floor. The hook doesnt take up alot of space, you could actually put quite a few of them side by side
and still have room. This hook holds alot of weight, my daughter being the clumsiest kid on the planet dropped her towel
in the shower when it was on and then she just grabbed it and stuck it on the hook and i was terrified it was going to
rip right off the wall but it held and we haven't had any problems with it coming loose. I love the smaller and bigger
versions of this that i have on my wall, i use the smaller one for my towel and my daughter gets this one because its
alot more heavy duty. I would definately recommend this to anyone looking for towl hooks that fit in small spaces and
hold tons of weight.
*Disclaimer*"I received this product for testing purposes but I am under no obligation to write or leave a positive review.
The choice was purely my own and I received No  compensation."
summary: Perfect for small spaces and holds a ton of weight

reviewText:
So, I received my  C2002-WK  today and immediately took it out of the box.  What a simple task that was!  I had read the reviews of this unit prior to purchasing it via Amazon.com, and paid particular attention the the review by Paul in reference to the break in period.  I set the unit outside, opened the tank relief valve, and let it run for  15 minutes.  Afterwards, I closed the valve and let the tank pressurize without  a glitch. Very happy with this wall art.  It takes time to install so be prepared.  You will receive a box with all the pieces and they are numbered.  They are written very large but the pen they used to write the numbers on did not always write well so it made it hard to read.  You do get a sheet of paper with a diagram of the leaves and where they go... LOL so small that even a magnifying glass would not help. The box also contains several sheets of paper that you hang on the wall as the template.  Take your time here and install it with the tape given on the top.  If it falls off the wall, you will have trouble.  When you remove the sticky back tape cover, where you put the piece it will stay.  Be careful here IT STICKS, if you try to remove it you will remove the paint on your wall as well.  Peel the paint right off the wall.  Suggest to make it easy you put all the numbers together by category and not in order.  So all the 2 digits by number but not necessarily in order as they keep the numbered pieces "fairly" close on the diagram.  I had to reach up under the paper to place the pieces as removing the cut out and placing the piece on the wall often led to me getting stuck on the paper.  Did I mention how sticky the back is.... yeah.  Sticky.  Good luck I really love the way it turned out.
summary: Get it right as the glue is pretty permanent

reviewText: To start, I don't totally dislike this light.  It has a lot of really nice features, but the bad ones far outweigh the good ones.  I bought a bunch of these for Christmas gifts and everyone who received one and tried them out were quite pleased.  Within three weeks, only 2 of six units were still intact, having come apart in purses, pockets, etc.  Those who were able to find all the parts (batteries, head unit) complained about getting all the batteries back in properly.  So I have been looking for something else in a similar size and light output.  The eGEAR Pico lite is close to a 5 star rating.  It has an o-ring that produces enough friction to keep the parts from self-rotating.  It also has a small battery holder, so you can assemble the batteries (four AG-41 as in the Streamlight) outside the unit and insert easily.  The price is about the same too.
summary: Once again, read reviews before buying

reviewText: Great for protecting my outdoor sandstone fire pit!!

I wanted to wait until I have used the saw extensively before passing judgment on the saw. I have found that a break in period i.e. learning curve is necessary for any type of new equipment especially something as often used as a table saw.

I bought the saw packages with the 52 fence, cast iron (steel) extension wings and mobile base. As other reviewers have noted, the blade that comes with the saw is something that should end up on a chop saw, not making rip cuts. Replaced this blade almost immediately with a Freud blade, could not be happier.

Assembly of the saw with all of the additional do-dads took a couple of day, spending an hour or two at a time. Instructions were generally straight forward, but would recommend going thru all of it before actually assembling the saw. Because of the 52 rails, some assembly needed to be removed to install rail components. Not a big deal, but added time to the entire assembly.

Now to the operation, saw was pretty set, right out of the box, with some minor tweeking.needed for fence. Powerful and quiet the best way describe the beast, I do a lot of ripping on 4/4 red oak and have had very little saw related issues. Fence remained dead on and repeatable cuts have not been a problem. Dust collection is fair, I have a steel city DC 1200 cfm connected but still I get a lot under the saw. Just recently (still waiting for shipment) invested in a true cut system to replace the stock one, never could get it to sit right...and with the addition of a Incra 5000, makes cross cuts a snap.

All in all, the saw was a good deal for the money spent, a year and 5-600 b/f of oak later, it might have been better to bite the bullet and get a cabinet saw, but what the heck, I can get another couple of years out of this one before looking for a replacement.
summary: After a Year owning the saw

Locking pliers are very much a staple tool in any garage or shop. After having to rely on c-clamps or other not the right tools, I had been watching for a good set. I ended up picking these and a handful of other Irwin tools during a sale, but Amazon has consistently been far less expansive than any of the big box stores locally for Irwin and the in-house brands.

I was drawn to these as they are the classic no-frills Vise-Grips that I grew up using. They may not have fancy release mechanisms but as so far they have been able to lock and hold whatever I am working on, or need to secure, without slipping. The quality seems fine for my purposes as someone who performs all my own automotive work, most of my home improvement and repair, and some welding here and there. As some of the reviewers mentioned these don't feel as nice as the older Irwin Vise-Grips. I grew up using those both at some of my early jobs and at home and there is a heft and feel difference. However, for the price and what I was able to find online and in stores these seem to fit the bill for what I need. and so far they have not shown any wear or had any issues. I have bought some of the cheaper products when I needed to make one-off tools and those would actually warp when being used with a good bit of force. So far these have held up, so while they may not be quality of before, as so far they are still good enough. As I continue to mention in tool reviews, if you rely on these to earn your money, you probably should invest in getting the best you can buy.
summary: Great starter set for homeowner/DIY, not quite the same as what you grew up with though.
