reviewText:
Great concept but design flaws/ tech issues. I want to first point out something I didn't notice until I gave up on this & decided to move it to a room where function wasn't so critical, due to not so great performance. On the unit, there is a range switch. Mine was set to lowest setting, but I didn't see it or know of it until I got fed up w/ it & went to move it. With the range set higher, now works better for coming on in the 1st place, but still have some issues w/ it not detecting that I'm still in the room. Some of these sensors work different ways, I'm not sure, but I do think it's supposed to know you're there w/o having to do the jive every now n then. Anyway, it still does go off on me when I'm still there, but seems to work better in that regard also now that range set to max.

Another issue is that for all of my outlets/surge protectors, etc...the main 3-prong plug-in unit is upside-down, so no matter what, you're covering 2 outlets & only getting one back. I used this on a lamp in my office-has 2 entries but 1 wall switch/light. I always enter thru the way w/ no switch. This was an OK solution, but light kept going out on me after a while in middle of work & it was harder to get back on than it should've be-doin' a wavy hand dance 1" from the sensor still took several seconds for it to come back on. A bit easier to reactivate now w/ range on high also, but still gotta wave at it once it cuts off. I haven't tried it back in the ofc. since changing the range, mainly cuz I got another solution there. It does work better now, but haven't exposed myself to it enuf to know how much better.

What I like about this-sensor can be wall-mounted w/ 2 small screws (or double-sided tape) not included if I recall, but has mounting holes for it-or it comes with a little desk/shelf stand. The concept is great, but execution- needs improvement. Also a negative-for me, the reach of the cord to the sensor is too short, unless you do wall-mount (even then maybe more cord preferred). I think a wall-mount in combo w/ a stick-on cord manager would make a clean look, on a budget & less time than alternative. Works well enough to get you in the room, would suggest having a 2nd light source for those pesky cut-offs though.

Another con-this comes on day or night. I just turn sensor towards the wall in the day. I solved the office issue w/ a small battery powered motion sensor LED light mounted to the wall (see other review for that product) which doesn't give off nearly as much light, but works for me to see where to step & turn on my desk lamp. The battery pwr LED's have a daylight sensor & only come on in the dark. I have no idea why, but the small motion sensors on those little $7.64 LED lights work incredibly well. So well, I know they're there but they still startle me sometimes! They were mis-advertised as being larger than they are, so originally bought them for main outdoor lighting, but they come in so handy everywhere, I kept them for other uses like this.

To me, the best solution would be to replace the wall switch with a quality motion-sensor switch (hard-wired), that detects presense by heat and movement, or just heat-something to keep it on no matter what, while you're there. But, the corded version is much less labor/ time/ money, so I feel OK about the purchase. It served my needs well enough & long enough & is still useful in another spot.

If not for the issues I mentioned, I would have given 5-stars.

reviewText:
This scraper is okay but has limited use.  The blade angles are such that you can not easily get under the old paint and push the old paint off.  Drag and scrape backward, yes; push, no.  The blade angle from the handle is about 120-125 degrees.  It should be a lot closer to 180 degrees to allow you to have the heat gun in one hand and the tool in the other and push the tool under the old paint immediately after the old paint is heated.  To remedy this, I put the blades into vise grips or channel locks which allows you to have the blade at a lower angle to the old paint.

Also, the tool does come with a variety of blade shapes but to change the blades and keep them tight you need a screw driver handy. Instead of a bolt with a flat head the tool should have a wing nut that you can open and tighten with your hand.  As soon as I find a wing nut that fits the opening, I will replace the existing bolt with the wing nut. But if you keep the blades handy, you can use the side of one of the blades to tighten or remove the bolt.  A wing nut would be a whole lot better.

Finally, I congratulate the designer for recessing the sharpening file into the handle with a magnet.  The file also has a curved side to sharpen the curved blades.  Obviously, this file is intended only for a quick fix, however. A filing stone is needed for long term use, as does all similar tools with blades like this.

UPDATE October 7, 2013.  I'm updating my review now that I have worked with--or I should say, attempted to work with--this tool on a big project.  I'm lowering my rating from two stars to one star. First the variety of profiles on the blades is excellent.  You get a total of 12 different profiles. For that they should get five stars.  The problem is as I said originally, and have now experienced on a big job, the design is extremely poor. The one angle that this tool gives you is not at all sufficient for most jobs.  Woodwork has all sorts of nooks and crannies at all sorts of angles.  For that you have to attack the nooks and crannies with tools and blades at all sorts of angles.  You can not do that with this tool. You get your one 120 degree or so angle and that's it.

Further, as Chris K commented to my original review, it is better to pull than to push when using a heat gun.  I agree.  But the further problem I discovered when trying to pull with this Allway tool is that you have to put the heat gun UNDER the tool when the tool is in effect in a closed position.  You simply can not get the heat gun aimed at the paint when the tool is in the way of the heat gun. Something has to give.  You either heat the area and hope after getting the Allway tool out of the way that the paint will remain sufficiently plyable and soft you will be able to lift the paint easily and quickly.  You simply can not work at a consistent pace with this tool with a heat gun.

But worse, and this is something I would not have believed until I experienced it,  is that the bottom portion of the toll where the blade rests in the tool is made out of PLASTIC!!!  This means when you aim the heat gun under the tool as close to the blade as possible you are MELTING the tool!!!

Still worse is the fact that you can only use one profile at a time and have to go thru the trouble of changing profiles in the midst of a job that may require many different profiles repeating over each other.  Each blade in the six blade set has two profiles on each end.  Problem is you can only use one at a time.

I also have the Robert Larson Shavehook set with three blades.  I know there is a lot of criticism of that took with the posts being round and the holds for the blades being square and this apparently has caused for some swiveling of the blades.  I haven't had this problem.  Just keep in tight with a small wrench nearby. But the point I'm making is that the multiple profile blades available with the Allway Tool can be used with Larson tool and as a result you are not wedded to the one angle as you are with the Allway.  You can have any angle you desire in which you position the tool.  And, of course, the Larson is made out of all metal.  It won't melt like the Allway.  You will have to use wide metal washers above and below the Allway blades to secure the blades onto the Larson tool, but that is a minimal inconvenience.  In fact, I don't consider it an inconvenience, it just the way the tool works. Also, with the Larson post, you can turn the post to any profile on any side of the blade you wish at anytime.

I now know why Allway offers a six pack of its tool at seemingly A discount volume price.  They want you to buy at least six because they knew you will go nuts trying to use just one.  It seems also that each tool in the six pack comes with the six blades (total 12 profiles.  That's a waste and needless expense.  If they are going to resort to this silliness, just sell six handles BUT MAKE SURE THE ARE MADE OUT OF ALL METAL SO THEY WON'T MELT WHEN USING THEM WITH A HEAT GUN!!!!

Having said all of this, seems that the two most important tools when stripping paint with a heat gun are an ice pick and a flexible putty knife.
heavy duty!!!

These are nice lights and work as advertised. We live in New England and the sun is low in the sky in December and we probably only get about 8 hours of direct sunlight on these every night,  but that has been enough to keep these lit all night,  every night.

There are some caveats as a result of the solar nature of these lights,  combined with the length an number of bulbs.

First,  these are tiny bulbs. They do project evenly over a wide angle,  but they aren't particularly bright. They are bright enough to be easily seen from some distance at night,  but even with two strings on one leaf bare bush,  they don't cast much light on the ground.

Second,  the built in battery cannot provide full brightness in all modes. If you want all the lights on steadily,  you only get half brightness. If you want steady light at full brightness,  that mode only lights half the lights, (every other bulb). The best compromise seems to be to select a blinking/twinkling/cascading mode.

Third,  while you can switch the lights off,  switching them on only activates the ambient light sensor. There is no power mode that forces the lights to light in a lit environment. There is also no timer mode. The light sensor works great for us as the solar panels/light sensor point away from our house and any street lights. We can turn our porch lights on with out these lights switching off. Others might have issues.

Note: if you have trouble with these,  make sure to try the different modes. I've seen negative reviews that clearly resulted from people not understanding the mode button.

reviewText:
This is a little spendy for a clamp for my taste, but it was a perfect fit for my track saw and I've really gotten in the habit of using throughout the shop when i need an extra hand.
My favorite use has been for clamping together joints that are at odd angles. Rather then clamping it across the joint, I can clamp the joint to the table as the glue sets. It's helpful cause i can use the clamp upside down and put the finger through a hole in the table right next to my joint. then put the joint together with glue and clamp the other side of the joint in the same fashion.

I ended up coming back and getting 4 more.

8/9/2016 - I use this to cut plugs that are used for pocket holes and it works very well.  As usual with this type of saw you need to let the saw cut on its own without forcing it.  The small rubber inserts actually do add grip to the handle.
This wood plate is well made- just not made out of oak. I have lots of oak throughout my house from antique to new and stained to natural, but this did not match anything.

This rule is accurate as delivered to better than 1/64th for both inside and outside measurements (when compared to a 2' Starrett rigid rule) although the sliding joint for the endhook needed a little exercising. In addition, the approach to blade control -- that it slides out easily, and retracts with the push of the button -- works well for me. I ordered the 16' (having already had the 12') not for the greater length but for the wider blade, to make it more rigid; this makes it less fiddly for reaching to the end of a piece of lumber. It is a bit heavier, but a good trade overall.

An update: at a certain point the blade lock no longer held the tape well, allowing it to slide slowly back into the reel. I used a thin fingernail file to roughen the brake and it now holds well; we'll see how often this needs to be done.
summary: Accurate, and an agreeably stiff blade

Additionally the color is very true to the picture - they are double sided with a light color on one side and a darker color on the other side.  Very quiet and the breeze is comfortable and really cools the room down.  Additionally the antique brass unit is very classic, there is an embossed stamp showing Hunter 1886 so it just adds to the classic look.  Can't go wrong with the price and ease of installation.

reviewText: Perfect for a student dorm room.

This is my 25th folder in my collection. ZT 's. Kershaws. Spyderco. ESEE. Ontario. These are what I stick with. I've had my Spyderco Endura for over 20 years. It's still solid. A true workhorse EDC. I've only recently started to acquire Spyderco knives. I got the Tenacious which I did with some hesitancy as it's made in China. I consider China knives as uncollectable. With that in mind, I'll put this knife through everything I can throw at it. Truth be told, it's a very well made knife. I was impressed. Now which Spyderco do I buy now? They make so many. I was ready to pull the trigger on the Endura 4. I love flat ground blades. At the last minute I see the Manix 2 in blue. As per usual, I search YouTube reviews along with Amazon's and any others I can. I loved the weight. 2.85 ozs? Really? I admit that I didn't care for the blue color at first but at the same time. Practically all
my knives are black! This translucent blue was cool.

So today I finally get my Manix 2. You know how it is. You simply can't WAIT to see the UPS truck pull up (and hope wifey doesn't see). I open the box up and even though I was expecting light, was really surprised at HOW light it is! You'd think it'd be blade heavy but it's balanced superbly. Just a delight.

At first I felt the action was a tad stiff to deploy the blade one handed with ease. After using the Kershaw Blur, you tend to get spoiled. But, Spyderco has thoughtfully placed Torx screws that allow adjustment of the pivot tension. I adjusted both sides by loosening them perhaps 1/8 of a turn. Maybe less. That did it! A very small amount of RemLube on all parts and now it flicks open nicely with one hand. Be careful doing this if you must. Check to see if you've allowed the blade to have any play in it. Mine has zero.

The sharpness of this blade wasn't exactly razor like. That's ok though. I like being able to place my own finishing on a knife blade. Sharpened up excellent. I don't need to shave my arm hair to convince me. It's perfect. It was a great day today and I wore my sweat pants. Put this knife in my pocket. Clipped on nice. Love the clip BTW. Even with sweats, the knife felt like it was there. Not many good folders with an almost 3.5 inch blade can do that!!

In summary:

Surprising weight.
Beautiful design/color
Great clip.
Excellent steel. Easily sharpened.
Beautiful lockup and action.
Great value overall.

Spyderco nailed this one. I'd like too see more colors.

Looks like I'm in trouble. I'll be buying a lot
more USA made Spyderco knives. Couldn't be happier with this purchase.
Great !!!!!

So the product is well made, very compact and handy. The problem I have is one of function. I can't seem to figure out when I would use it. Generally if I need a utensil while backpacking I am eating freeze dried meals like Mountain House, however trying to use this tiny spork inside an 8" bag is messy to say the least. Folding the bag down is messy, cutting the bag in half has lead to disasters during the process and while eating, and even then isn't small enough to not get messy hands as your knuckles drag the sides. I suppose if I packed a bowl and transferred the food to the bowl before eating it would work, but that defeats the compact nature of the spork.

My final idea is to build my own freeze dried or just add water meals and then I could potentially use this spork while directly eating from my MiniMo, but I haven't had the time to test that theory.

TLDR: Cool, well made product that has no real function for my general backpacking.
summary: Generally if I need a utensil while backpacking I am eating freeze dried meals like Mountain House

I recently purchased a DeWalt Belt Sander and discovered the long extension cord wasn't heavy duty enough to power the sander without overheating so I bought this US Made Power-On 12 gauge cord. It's well constructed, fully grounded and polarized, rated 15 amp, 125V, 1875 watt. It even has a red glow light to indicate the cord has power. The cord has an SJTW vinyl jacket that won't crack in temperatures down to -35, is neon yellow and has a lifespan of fifteen years.
The cord is double insulated with solid molded plugs. Outer jacket will not mar floors or walls and is resistant to abrasion and deterioration from moisture and sunlight. Temp-Flex-35 was developed to meet the demands of contractors for a super flexible vinyl cord set.

I am very pleased with the weight and quality, and the price is considerably less than similar US made cords.
summary: Great quality at a low price

reviewText: If you are going to buy a tool, go big. This product is not for the wimps out there. Heavy duty, big, heavy. Good quality hose. Install tip: if mounting on ceiling or wall, secure reel to 2x8 (recess lag bolts on board side so board is flush with finished wall, use washers and nuts so there is metal on metal securing), and use lag screws to secure board onto wall/ceiling. I used a 2X6 and was only able to position it parallel with board. A 2x8 would have allowed perpendicular or parallel positioning. One of those "If I could do this differently."

A good sharpener for your knives that have a decent (but dull) blade. The holder and "stone" are good quality, holding the "stone" firmly and being stiff. It's taking a little "getting used to" to sharpen my knives with this diamond stone (vs the traditional honing stone), but after a few  less than successful attempts I finally have the hang of it and can (and have) put a decent edge on all the kitchen straight knives and my pocket knives.

Don't try to use this with a serrated blade, it won't work, otherwise, it's goof for most normal blade lengths.

You may want to consider a sharpening guide if you're getting this, like me, without much experience. The guide will help you avoid scratching the finished surface of the blade (if that's important to you) and will help put the right angle on the cutting edge so you don't round the current one or blunt the edge.
summary: Good stone - technique not included. Consider a guide!

reviewText:
Ok, great pump, the 1 hp sucks out my whole big sized sump pump pit in 5 seconds, my old 1/3 hp pump was from a big box store, is 10 years old, I have 2 of these pumps, both over 10 years old, working like a champ, but with recent floods in my area increasing, we wanted more power, got it in this Wayne.

I will buy another for my second pit in a month if this Wayne holds up well.

Heres my problem with this unit, the metal rod holding the float looks flimsy, as other reviewers have stated, also the Wayne manual suggests changing the float switch every 2 years, never had to do this with my other standard sump pumps. Vertical  swithch in this unit is great, but I have a feeling I'll be changing the float and the switch within 5 years at most.

Instructions on the internet how to do this are available, the float is 35 bucks on amazon, the switch is 20. So not a big deal, I ordered this unit knowing all this from the reviews.

Guess I'm spoiled by having 3 regular sump pumps, 1 lasted 7 years, the other 2 are 10 years old and still working, so I believe the Wayne motor may last 10 years, but maintenance on the float  and swithch sort of sucks, but any vertical float switch may not last as long as the older floats, idk

At least with the Wayne unit you can replace the float and swithch more easily then your standard pump.

This pump is great, but will be a long time in trusting this unit to last, I will update as time goes by.

My sump pump pit is large, so a regular float be fine by me, but none are available at this high horsepower with good ratings, so trying the vertical model, and hope for the best, if I do order a second pump, I will order the float assembly and swithch, I figure out of 2 of these units I will be changing one or the other within 5 years or less, so I'll have my 2 older sump pumps ready just in case, and keep the parts on hand instead of waiting to order them when needed,  we will see

All research on the internet has Wayne pumps one of the highest, and most affordable compare to zoeller pumps, 3 times price wise of this Wayne pump for a 1 hp.

Time will tell, love the pump, just not really confident in getting 5 years out of it without replacing the float or switch, and the 5 year warranty from reading their manual sounds like it will be tougher to get the unit fixed if needed, but just my gut feeling on this.

I'm not using pvc pipes, never have, I use the black hose to be flexible when needed, makes it easy to change out the pump when needed,. I bought the check valve but didn't use it, it's made for pvc pipe, not the black flexible hose I use, no biggie, I like the water flushing back in, helps clean out any  debris that may try to clog the unit.

Also I'm using a heavy duty 3 pronged extension cord even though the manual suggest not too, the cord is only 7 feet or so long, I've used it on my other sump pumps much cheaper, so Wayne has to suck it up and work with a heavy extension cord, so far so good, next flood I can tell better when unit runs for 30 mins or so non stop.

So I say this Wayne unit for the price cant beat it, but must be willing to change float or swithch when needed. Unless you just buy a new one, much cheaper to replace the parts.

Just wish Wayne had more confidence in their product so I could be,

5 stars until I see any reason to change it, giving Wayne the benefit of the doubt, as far as noise, very quiet pump, I checked the screws on the unit to insure they were tight, all were. Seems heavy but not overly too much, I don't care if the body rusts a bit, sure it will be surface rust only, not affecting the units functioning.

I helped myself by capping both of my drains in basement and crawl space, as all went into the yard inside the ground, every flood water came rushing into my house because of this, now water comes in during a flood still but much slower, so 2 sump pumps are for my piece of mind in case we get a major flood like last year, 18 inches of water in my basement, 1200 dollars to repair my furnace, lucky my hot water tank survived, its an 80 gallon beast for my jetted spa bathtub.

So investing in Wayne to prevent this damage next major flood, lived in my house 20 years and last years flood was the worst of my 56 years on this planet, scared me straight, so more power now, hate floods but curious if we get another major flood how this pump will keep up running for 3 hours straight as my other ones had to, that will be the true test.

Mother Nature can be nasty, but hopefully Wayne's helps even the odds next battle, I'll update again when I got more to add, I will order another for my second pit soon, starting to gain confidence in the pump, ty gl
summary: Great pump, just makes me nervous

reviewText:
After reading many reviews I decided go with the pipe clamps and hope to get some parallel clamps down the road.  After receiving these, I took a trip to the local home store and bought few of the 10' black pipes.  I cut them in half and since the threaded ends threads into these clamps one end, you only have to move one end to secure an item you're trying to clamp down.

Sure, it's bulky but for the price it does the job very well.  I've bought few of the Bessey parallel clamps since and while there's the height advantage and more surface area with parallel clamps, these H-style pipe clamps feel more than adequate for many tasks!  I've built medicine cabinets with them already and getting to build a kitchen island cabinets.  I didn't bother going with the 1/2" and while again, it's on a bulkier side but unless you need 5' setup like I did any shorter clamps shouldn't weigh that much.  I may buy more down the road as it's cost effective overall.
summary: Great holding strength for glue up and woodworking!

This is a handy little drill for light jobs.  Overall I'm well please with it but the price for these batteries is outrageous!  Watch for sales and you'll soon find you can buy the whole kit, drill, charger and battery for about $30, that's for the whole kit, not just the battery.  Over Christmas I bought 3 additional kits at one sale for $24.99 each, so now I have 4 drills, 4 chargers and 4 batteries for less than the price of 2 extra batteries alone as sold here.

By the way, if your a bit handy and and can solder well you can buy raw cells for these battery packs.  You'll need to have a good quality soldering station with tempature control and a fine tip. Go to batteries.com or any of the many vendors selling the individual cells, the kind you want are 18560, 3.7 volts at around 3000 mh.  The cost is between 3$ & 5$ per cell and you'll need three to completely rebuild the pack.  Take out the 4 screws and open the pack. Carefully unsolder the electronics board from the batteries and measure the voltage on each of the 18560 cells, you'll probably find only one is below 3 volts and the other 2 will likely be about 3.6 volts, these are still usable if you want.  So if you're handy and your soldering skills are good then you can save a ton of money by doing the rebuild yourself, and in any case, it doesn't cost anything to try.
summary: Good drill but a silly price for the batteries

reviewText:
I was expecting a five start rating.  And I just received the saw today.  So what went wrong?
The manufacturing and fit and finish of the saw seems just fine.  Typical DeWalt, with good quality. I like the layout of the saw, giving it less length for fitting in small places.
So what is wrong?  The minor things are that the trigger could be a little larger, which would help with gloved hands.  Similar saws I have used have two finger wide triggers, and it makes a difference.  I don't know why Dewalt didn't include a max speed control.  Cutting metal with this could be a pain to keep the blade running slow.  The trigger controls the speed, but there is no dial for the maximum speed.  Not nice.  But here's the biggie:  Let me preface by saying that I am a big guy.  Huge.  But this saw vibrates so much that my forearm hurt after 3 to 4 minutes of playing with it. (Just to compare, I tried my Skill brand 110V (don't laugh, cost me $39) powered recip saw, and it is easily 1/10 the perceived vibration.) I have run rotary drills, hammer drills, and demo jack hammers with less vibration.  I didn't have gloves on.  It vibrated my arms and shoulder so much that my glasses slid down.  I don't see anyone grabbing this saw to trim brush and tree limbs, which I thought would be an advantage of a cordless recip saw.
DeWalt, get your kinematics people to address the vibration.

So to summarize, in order of importance: excessive even extreme vibration, no max speed control, and trigger size.
summary: The manufacturing and fit and finish of the saw seems just fine. Typical DeWalt

reviewText:
I bought an Oxygenics 60120 7 years ago.  It did great with my moderate well water pressure, nice spray pattern and nice pressure.  The 60120 is still working fine, but has some calcium buildup on it, so I decided to buy a new one and clean up the old one to put in the downstairs bathroom..

The 60120 doesn't seem to be available any more, so I bought this 27267.  It looks exactly the same but it doesn't work the same.  The flow is insufficient.  The spray pattern isn't good, and the pressure is lousy.  Big disappointment.

Now that I read closer, the 60120 claimed 2.5 GPM flow, and the 27267 claims 2.0 GPM.  I guess that .5 GPM makes a big difference.

I took photos of the old and new inlets, you can see on the left that the old 60120 has a noticeably bigger hole, which is probably why it works better.
summary: Insufficient flow and poor spray pattern compared to old Oxygenics 60120

A couple of notes about the iDevice I found in the last few days:

iDevice Pros: The LED lights is very bright, love the side plug design.

Cons: The thickness removes flexibility from the adjacent plug.  Not a huge loss if you're planning on using the night light feature

Neutral: The "night light" appears as an additional icon in the Homekit.  The brightness and color can also be adjust through Homekit so the iDevice app is not required neither for setup or changes.  While the energy readout feature is lost to my interest without helping me track of ALL my energy usage.

The iDevice App: If you do choose to download the app this app can turn connect to ALL your homekit devices including non-iDevices.  This can be a good thing or a bad thing pending on how you see it.  As for me, I plan to grow my Homekit arsenal using devices that can be controlled by the app WITHOUT access to other homekit devices.  For instance, iHome's app can only access its own devices which allows me to build an iHome only room controlled by my kids without having to relinquish control over the whole house to them.
summary: Observations of the iDevice and its app

reviewText:
I've owned this faucet for a little over a year now and am ready to throw it out!

It was not particularly easy to install and fit everything under the counter / behind my deep basin sink. But I got it to work, it worked ok for about a year and then it just stopped cooperating, it is difficult to turn on or off by touch, yet it will turn on all by itself...

Now, it turns on when nobody is around at least once a day, if not more, as others have said, it's like there is a ghost in your house wasting your water.

Be aware that it doesn't come with an adapter plate if you have a sink with more than one hole in the center. Also for whatever reason they decided not to bother fully assembling the faucet. The two hoses that connect the body  to the water supply do not come installed, and I needed to disassemble the bottom of the unit to properly install. I have never had this experience buying other faucet brands and don't understand the advantage of doing it this way.

 On an up note it dose feel sturdy and I like the finish has plenty of pressure, and I like the spring detractor vs hoses with weights on it.

Vary nice built does not feel cheap and has a length. Folds to a nice size for transport and extends for greater length, it's the closest to a full size shovel but more compact. Also you can change the degree of the shovel blade from straight, 50 degree to a 90 degree angle. The saw is vary useful it can cut down small trees no thicker than 5-6 inches. The one flaw is despite the nice coating that allows material to slide off easy. It wears off when used against rough surfaces like rock, and it is a high carbon which means rust could form over time. A way to fix this is after each use wipe it dry to ward off rust, Feel free to ask any questions.

First, a note on how Bluetooth LE (Low Energy) operates. It doesn't need to be manually paired to the device to work, so you won't find it on your list of Bluetooth devices. If you select a wall in the app, then click the Laser button, it will find and show your laser measure and allow you to connect to it. After that, it holds that connection through the rest of the session. This is in the help section of the app.

The software they are using is a branded version of Magic Plan. Luckily, the non-branded version of Magic Plan can be used with the Stanley laser, so no need to use a special version of it. I generally avoid branded versions of software. They tend to be backlevel, and have less support than the original version.

As far as construction goes, it is equivalent to my more expensive Disto unit. Still, I was hoping it would have a more robust feel. It may not survive on a job site, though these devices tend to be used by real estate agents after the house is built, rather than during. Just don't drop it, and you'll be fine.

The Magic Plan app is much, much better than the almost laughable app that the Disto comes with. That one is not easy to use, does very little, and allows you to save the floorplan in only one format, a picture. Yes, you read that correctly. A picture, and it puts it right in the picture gallery with the other thousand or so pictures you've already taken. This one will do all the major formats, but costs $3 per plan. If you are using this for personal use, like I am, that is $3 well spent. For professionals, they have monthly subscription plans.

So, Magic Plan is pretty great, though there is definitely a learning curve, because it is powerful. It gets even better, however. Magic Plan works with Floorplanner, which is a web-based system for drawing floor plans and decorating. So, you can create the plan for your home with Magic Plan, then use Floorplanner to put in furniture and create 3D renderings of your rooms. There is a cost for this, but it is $5 for a single project, which means that if you are just doing your own home, it is $5 and you are done. Annoying, perhaps, but again, money well-spent.

The device itself is easy to spot due to its yellow jacket color scheme. It has a rubberized grip to make it less likely you will drop it. And you won't want to, because my feeling is that this isn't going to survive much of a drop. It is lightweight, which is good, but it isn't rugged like a piece of construction equipment. It is easy to use its most basic function, which is to measure the distance to an object, most commonly, a wall. According to the packaging, it can do volume calculations, presumably by measuring ceiling heights and factoring that in. It is easy to get the ceiling height - just place it on the floor aimed up, and press the measurement button. How to do the volume stuff? Well, it is in the manual. I wasn't interested in that because it really isn't useful for me. If I were sizing rooms for HVAC vents or something, it might be somewhat useful. After you have the measurements, though, doing simple calculations like volume isn't difficult, so I really doubt these additional features beyond measurement and bluetooth capability, are used much, by anyone.

Personally, I think this is a great alternative to the Disto. However, the Disto is very, very common in the real estate profession, so if you are planning on using this with a particular piece of software, you'll want to see if it supports the Stanley before buying. Disto support can practically be assumed because of its popularity. The Stanley? Not so much.

Overall, recommended. Especially if you are using this for personal use, and are only doing one or two houses with it.

Sean Logue, 2015
summary: Where we are going, we won't need wheels!

reviewText: I was a design engineer for many years and appreciate a product that is well thought out and executed. The Wooster Brush Sherlock GT pole is a well-designed tool. It has a light weight, fiberglass outer sleeve and a hexagonal, aluminum inner pole. That combination results in a stiff, light weight assembly and the inner pole will not turn inside the sleeve. The features that really set it apart from the typical extension pole are the click-to-set extension length and the bayonet tool attachment. Setting the length with the push of a button means that you will adjust the length more frequently to obtain the optimum length because it's just so easy! Granted, the length is adjustable only in 6" increments, but that's really no problem at all. Once you experience the Sherlock GT system, you'll never to back to a twist-lock and screw-on roller extension! Being able to install and uninstall a brush, tool or roller with a button push means that you can dip the brush or apply paint to the roller without the cumbersome extension attached. Makes for a much neater, easier and quicker application of paint. I found that I could use the pole with a roller attached at any extension length. Guiding a 16' pole with a roller is a handful, but the Wooster Sherlock GT did it as well as could be expected, with minimum bending and no twisting of either the lock or the tool. I also used the Wooster Sherlock GT with a Mr Longarm Brush/Tool Holder Extsn Kit 0650 to cut in ceiling lines with mixed results. The Wooster Sherlock GT did its job perfectly. The limitation is mainly in the ability of the painter to see the line clearly enough to do a satisfactory job. I found that I could work a line no more than 4' to 6' above my head before I reached the limit of my 20-15 vision. Pros: Relatively light weight. Very stiff; minimal bending. No slipping or rotation of extension. Quick on and off of tools and rollers. Con: Nothing I can think of. The 8' - 16' model is a lot of pole to handle, so remember that when you are choosing the length (shorter models available).

I did screw it directly to the door as it slapped around too much with the hangers. My door is a hollow core door so I used slightly oversize screws instead of anchors. If you do it this way you have to ensure not to over tighten them and strip out the thin holes. Also use a couple more than you think it needs to make sure it is secure. Another thing to note when installing it is not to put it too close to the edge where it would interfere with the door stop trim. Also make sure to make your measurements taking into account the door knob to ensure you will clear it.

reviewText:
I bought this based on universally positive reviews at a dozen websites
First impressions
Well designed and constructed of quality materials.  Overall has a quality "look and feel" of a more expensive unit.
Box was very sturdy, and had a number of cardboard supports to isolate the saw in the box, but the cardboard under the saw wasn't overly thick, and a number of reviewers reported broken feet, likely due to rough handling somewhere along the line.  My saw had all four feet in good condition.
"Instructions" are in Japenglish with postage stamp "illustrations" showing assembly "details", but there aren't too many ways to put it together, so anyone with basic mechanical skill should be able to assemble it easily.  It took me less than a half hour from opening the box to doing test cuts. YouTube videos can assist with any assembly problems.
When "folded" at 45 deg miter and 45 deg bevel, the saw is compact, saves space in my garage/shop, and is light enough to be easily trans-portable for storage or use elsewhere.
Out of the box, the blade was set at a perfect 90 degrees both vertically and horizontally
The thumb indexing for the preset stops is easy and intuitive, and is made of spring steel that will be less prone to breakage than the plastic versions on some other saws.  For off-index angles, the large table handle is threaded to press the indexing spring against the table to hold the saw in place.
The saw has a large pin behind the motor that inserts into a deep hole in the saw body to lock the saw up, and temporarily will hold the saw down when inserted into a shallower hole in the saw body.
A "T" socket wrench and hex wrench are attached in a rubber holder to the top of the saw for changing the blade and making adjustments
The saw handles small pieces easily, but because of its light weight it moves easily, so I will likely bolt it to a plywood base that can be clamped to a work table for handling larger items.
Operation is so easy a cave man could do it - plug it in, place the work piece on the table (hold or clamp in place), stay away from the moving parts, pull the trigger, let the saw spin up to speed and move it down slowly thru the piece... The ergonomics of the saw handle and trigger are very comfortable.
I purchased a 100 tooth blade for crosscutting and "finer work" but the 24 tooth blade that was installed cut smoothly and made a true 90 degree cut.
The laser works OK indoors, but might be a bit weak in bright sunlight
PROS
Price
Design and construction
Indexing system
"Off index" securing handle
"T" wrench and hex wrench attached to the saw
Laser
CONS
Instruction book is all but useless, but basic mechanical skill and YouTube are your friends!

So far, a great value single bevel saw.
Very good material

My husband has sharpened every knife in this house since getting this.  He had a whetstone but it was looking pretty bad so he bought a metal stone and didn't like that at all.  He likes this one because of it's size and quality.  He said that with the angle of the stone it makes it so easy to use.  Does it sharpen well?  Yes! My kitchen knives are sharper now than they were when I bought them actually.  I was threatening to go buy all new knives because mine were beyond dull and dangerous to use.  He had sharpened them a couple of months ago with his metal sharpening tool but they didn't sharpen much.  After using this whetstone I will now not have to go and buy a new set.  The stone itself is just a little over 4 inches long and 1 and half inches wide.  It's the perfect size to sharpened just about any knife you own. The plastic case it is on makes it even easier to use, the stone doesn't slip around so you don't run such a big risk of cutting yourself.  I'm impressed because my husband loves it and he is a very picky man when it comes to his knives.  I will come back and update this review in a couple of months to reflect how well the stone is holding up to normal use.  It is getting an honest workout because not only has my husband sharpened all our knives but has begged others to allow him to sharpen theirs too.  I received this product at a discounted price in exchange for my honest and unbiased opinion of the product after testing it out myself.  I have no relationship with the seller and never promise a good review in exchange for any discounts I might receive.

I put the glove on and started prepping some veggies for some stir fry.  I was dicing up some celery when I noticed something strange mixed in on the cutting board.  Long story short it turned out to be the entire tip of the glove that was supposed to protect my left fore finger.

reviewText: These filters arrive much more quickly than I expected and they fir my rather odd-ball sized filter plenum perfectly. reviewText:
This product fits most grounded outlets in Italy. If you have grounded devices such as laptops, this is an improvement over a 2 pin adaptor.

What it does not do:
1) It does not transform power. It just passes through 220v power.  If you need 120v, you need to buy a transformer. (Read your power adaptor.  Many laptops and camera battery chargers can take both 120v and 220v power.  Some cannot.  Do not plug a 120v device into this plug without a transformer.)

2) Occasionally one finds a recessed plug in Italy.  The dimensions of this adaptor will not fit into the recessed plug.

3) In older buildings one may find non-grounded outlets.  You will need a 2 prong adaptor to fit these outlets.

4) I have never run into plugs in Italy with prong spacing other than what comes with this adaptor however elsewhere in Europe there are different spacings.

I have 2 of these grounded adaptors and also carry 2 two prong adaptors and a transformer that transforms 220v to 120v current with me when I go to Italy.  The 2 prong adaptors are good for non-grounded applications such as most battery chargers for camera batteries.  The 2 prong adaptors can be plugged into most if not all grounded plugs in Italy.

I recommend both types of adaptors if you are going to Italy and need grounded plugs for some of your applications.  If you have no devices that require grounding there would be no need for a grounded adaptor.  My laptop requires a grounded connection.

Took the Rat 1 outside after close inspection and trimmed limbs and part of the trunk,bark etc. off of a tallow tree. The Rat 1 would still shave!! and slice through notebook paper like butter!! The feel of this knife in hand is excellent. Built solid with more screws in the handle and larger screws in the blade pivot pin. Everything was carefully locktighted with blue locktight. Blade deployment was smooth but a little stiff. Adjusted the tension slightly on the liner lock and also the blade pivot pin screws, relocktighted them,applied rem oil to blade,pivot,and lock, and good to go, smooth as silk! No blade play whatsoever,solid lockup. The Rat 1 is only about one sixteenth thicker, five eights longer, and about three eights more narrow than the Tenacious from back to blade in the closed position. The available cutting edge area is almost identical. The Rat 1 is slightly heavier but I can not tell the difference when carried in my front pocket.  There appears to be a small ball bearing made into the lock mechanism for smoother operation. The attention to detail appears to be spot on. The Rat 1 is not like a big huge knife as compared to the Tenacious, just slightly longer which makes for a great fit and feel in the hand! The Rat 1 can be deployed very fast or very slow without wrist action if you so choose. This is important because we work in a college around students, professors etc., and sometimes prefer a slower deployment. The different texture between the two knives on the handles as far as grip is very minute with wet or dry hands. The Rat 1 out of the box was awsome, I just wanted a slightly easier blade deployment. The Rat 1 is in my pocket now! Background: former USAF Helicopter Crew Chief and State of Texas Master Electrician. Have a good day!!

reviewText:
First Alert SA305CN smoke alarm.
Appears to work well, at least tests OK.  Good Price for 10 year life unit.  One thing, though... Once I screwed the mounting ring to the ceiling, I noticed that putting the alarm in place requires only a slight turn (maybe 5 degrees of rotation).  There is no resistance (like a detent) to counter rotation that will cause the alarm to fall from the mounting ring.  I happened to brush against the edge of the alarm with my forearm and it fell off the ceiling... fortunately I caught it!  Addition of a detent would be appreciated.  I placed a small square of double-faced tape between the top the the alarm body and the mounting ring to provide a small amount of anti-rotation resistance.
summary: First Alert SA305CN smoke alarm...  Wear your Hard Hat!  (for 10 years)

reviewText:
I am impressed with the way these light bulbs look. Not only does the full length of the 'filament' glow when they are on, but they have a warm, slightly orange color to them, making them look very much like incandescent bulbs. In fact, I wasn't convinced it was really an LED bulb, until I touched it and realized how cold it was even after being on for a while. I could only begin to discern the individual LEDs when the bulb was very dim. Which leads to the one feature that is less than ideal. Although these bulbs dim remarkably well in terms of light output, probably getting to less than a quarter of the brightness of other dimmable LED bulbs I have, there is a noticeable flicker to them as they get dim. Though to be fair, that may not be a problem if using a dimmer specifically made for LED bulbs.
I bought this at a discounted price in exchange for an honest review.
summary: Looks amazing at full brightness; dims very well in terms of light level, but with some flicker.

reviewText: I know at Auto stores that stuff isn't cheap.  I needed one 15a fuse for my horn, and I knew if I went to an Auto store it'd cost me like 3 dollars just for a fuse.  So I checked Amazon.com and this kit had 150 pieces plus some great tools.  It has a socket tester, alligator clip, and a tweezers.  The auto tester is very nice to see if juice is coming through for the sockets.  I think the light inside it lights up if it is good.  The tweezers are nice and long for pulling hard to get fuses.  The alligator clip is used to install fuses I believe.  Anyways, this kit is great and comes with a great variety of fuses.  For 8.50 plus amazon prime shipping I got this for a steal.  Even for regular shipping is about 12 dollars all said and done, this is still a great deal.  I would have paid up to 20 dollars for this kit.

How many numbers should you use?
From the reviews I am getting ready to purchase this lock. My big question was, "What is best number of digits to use and how many different combinations can be created since it does not matter what order the numbers are pressed? For example, the code 1,2,3 would open the lock whether you pressed 1,2,3 - 3,2,1 or 2,1,3. The order does not matter, only the numbers. If you set all 10 numbers and pressed all of the numbers the lock would open because the order does not matter. So I wondered how secure would the lock be and what are the optimum number of digits to use to make the lock the most secure?

I found a website that calculates the possibilities WITHOUT taking into account the number of permutations. Below are the possible combinations based on the number of digits used.
1=10, 2=45, 3=120, 4=210, 5=252, 6=210, 7=120, 8=45, 9=10, 10=1

This may help you decide how many digits to use for maximum security. The obvious answer is 4 or 5. Four is easier to remember but 5 gives you the maximum security.

I hope this helps someone to decide how many digits to use. I will update this review when I've installed the lock but this information is something that you need before you set your combination.

I chose 4 stars because although the lock seems to be super sturdy and reliable, a maximum of 252 codes is not the highest security. Trying a code every five seconds would allow me to crack the lock in less than 30 minutes but for practical non super high security use it should work fine.
summary: How many numbers or digits should you use?

reviewText:
This is the largest but still practical Swiss Army Knife in existence to actually use.  The insert from the packaging states 80 tools for collectors, but I consider this knife to be a user.

Unlike the other Swiss Army Knives which have a Matte or Glossy finish, this has a textured, clear red scale.  This features two electronic components, the LED LIGHT and the Digital Clock, timer, altimeter, barometer and alarm.

For daily use, this have almost every practical tool imaginable.  A pen, knife, bottle opener, screwdriver, Torx set, ruler, tweezers, magnifying glass, scissors, wire cutters, pliers, wire splitter and splicer, pen, and filer.

Sure you can get multiple different tools but what else has the flair of being all on the same gadget?  This is the James Bond version of the Swiss Army knife and I realize he was Scottish.

There aren't many things that you cannot do with this.  Well, you can start a fire with the magnifier.  But, it won't change a tire for you.  These types of gadgets will have some limitations.  Whether you're hiking, hunting, camping or just around the house, this will serve so many daily purposes that you will wonder how you lived without it.

This knife system as a whole is beefy and thick.  It's as wide as an iPhone but thicker.  It's almost 1 pound in weight.  Sure, you can put it into your pocket but at this kind of price, you might as well splurge for a holster.

This can easily fit into a hunting backpack, fanny pack, cargo pants pocket, Murse/Manpurse or woman's purse.

The construction is solid and it is backed by a strong warranty.  Replacement parts can get expensive if you lose stiff continuously over time.

Sure, the cost is about the same as a high end handbag, decent watch, a good set of large Bluetooth speakers, or a nice set of binoculars, but the function really surpasses just the novelty of a knife system like this.

There aren't any other gadgets that can do so much for you at this price point...especially, at the expense of size and practicality.

This is the ultimate knife system.

reviewText:
First of all, if you buy this bulb you need to understand the color temperatures of lighting.  If you don't do some research.  This bulb claims a CRI of 95%.  I also have TCP bulbs at 5000K with a claimed CRI of 82%.  I will say that the indoor sunshine bulb looks much better.  I was expecting that the better color rendition would be responsible for the difference but there is another factor.  Comparing side by side the color actually looks about the same to me, but the indoor sunshine bulb looked more stable which made me feel relaxed.  Looking at their website, they claim the ballast on these bulbs operates at 50,000 cycles per second which is very fast.  I believe this is responsible for the perceived stability and I would bet that the typical CFL is running much lower.

Overall it doesn't beat the light quality that is offered by certain Xenon M16's and perhaps a select few LED's such as the Soraa also in MR16.  However, these are standard screw base bulbs with high efficiency and so I will not compare them.  As far as CFL's go, at this color temperature, these are the best I have seen.

About a year ago, I bought a cheaper version of this screen. Since I have never had one of these screens before, I didn't know what to expect and I had no basis for comparison. But I know that I was not happy with the cheap version.

I decided to give the Bug Off Instant Screen a chance because of the good reviews. The short story is this: Bug Off is a far superior screen.

The adjustable bar for hanging the screen works very well: it especially allows you to adjust the screen so that it perfectly covers the door opening at the top and bottom--an obvious advantage for crawling and jumping insects (I always used to get crickets in the house because they would squeeze through the bottom of the screen and the floor). The magnets are strong, and the velcro fasteners (which I am not using) are well placed.

This may not be the perfect solution, but for $43 (the 48" version), it sure beat buying a retractable screen for $400.

This is a great solution if you want to have some extra light at the front door, but don't want to keep a regular light on all the time (or on a timer or sensor). Although the light is small and unobtrusive, it puts out quite a bit of light - no problems at all seeing who is at the door when the light is on high.

I like that it is solar powered since it makes installation very flexible. Just make sure it gets some sunlight during the day, and you're good to go.

It has two operating modes. It runs in "low" mode when it gets dark, which shines just a small amount of light. About the same as a low-wattage night light. However, when the sensor is triggered by movement, it switches to high power. That puts out more than enough light to read by, and easily lights up my front steps.

IMPORTANT: the light comes out of the box in "off" mode. You have to insert a supplied key (sort of looks like an unbent paper clip) into a small hole on the front to get it to turn on. That's done, according to the manual, to keep the light from operating when it's being shipped. There's also a plastic film that needs to be removed from the top of the solar panel. So, if you think the light is dead on arrival, don't forget to check that you've done those two steps!

The build quality is nice. Nothing fancy, but it has a sturdy aluminum bracket. The light lens is plastic. The colors (white and silver) blend well with pretty much any color scheme.

Very pleased with this, and highly recommend it as a front door security light.

[Manufacturer provided the product for review]
summary: Excellent security light for the front door

I'm very happy that there are now LED appliance bulbs like these, because for some reason I've had to replace more appliance bulbs over the last several years than any other type of bulb in my house.

These worked well in my over-the-range microwave, replacing the bulb on the bottom that provides light on the stove.  This bulb seems to provide at least as much light as the 40W bulb it replaced.  As others have noted, this bulb is not a typical "warm white" and is not nearly as warm as the incandescent bulb it replaced on my microwave.  However, the whiter light is perfectly fine and I have no complaints about the light color.

I was a little worried about the bulb fitting, as it is slightly longer than the standard 40W incandescent bulb it replaced, but it fit fine and my microwave had plenty of room for it.

My microwave has two brightness settings (high, low, off) and while the bulb works fine in the high and low settings, when I turn the light off, the bulb stays on just a bit, providing a dim light--it doesn't turn off fully.  I'm assuming this is a quirk of my particular microwave and that it is obviously still sending some current to the bulb.  Given how little electricity the bulb uses, it's not an issue for me, and it actually serves as a handy night light in the kitchen.
summary: Great LED replacement bulb. Dimming behavior may vary depending on your microwave.

I have now replaced nearly 75 bulbs in my house with Cree bulbs and Ecosmart cans with Cree tech.  My electrical bills are running almost 60% of where they were before I started buying.  If I didn't have to run the air conditioner, the drop would be more dramatic.

One important aspect of the Cree bulbs over the competition is the dimming function.  Some competitor bulbs still glow, even when the dimmer is turned all the way down.  Cree bulbs turn all the way off.  A rep at Lutron explained that some dimmers still have a small amount of current running to the light when turned all of the way down.  LEDs are so efficient, that even the smallest amount of current can cause light emissions.

There is a ten year warranty.  Save your receipts, but I've never had one go bad and I own nearly 75.

reviewText:
This is a wonderful ladder but PAY ATTENTION: THE CLOSED LENGTH IS 100".  You might think an "8-foot ladder" would fit under your 8-foot ceilings.  It will when open (it's about 93" tall; See photo). Just to be clear: eight feet is 96 inches; your "eight foot" ceilings may not be exactly 96 inches!

I bought this ladder with the intention of storing it behind a door in a room with eight foot ceilings.... that's not happening.  And no, it won't fit under a bed.  So unless you have a tall room you're not going to store it upright.  And behind a door requires a minimum of 5 " for width ... trust me on this.

As usual Amazon's Product Dimensions aren't accurate.  My measurements above are accurate.

After I figured this out I asked for a return and the seller agreed without any push-back.  But this is so nice in every other way, I canceled the return and decided to store this in my garage (9-foot ceiling) and order the six-foot model of this ladder for inside the house.

So what do I like?  Very light ladder, very stable, 300-pound rating (225 on the 6-foot model), wide top step, the little catch-all at the top, the locking mechanism and the locking drawer (!) for small screws/nails/etc in the wide step.
summary: Will  NOT fit upright under  8-foot ceilings when FOLDED.

This little device fixes the problem you may have with radiant wall heaters that only have an on/off switch.
With a little adjusting, this device will let your heater (or air conditioner) come on only when needed and stop you from having to manually control the temperature.
The controller comes with back-up batteries but, it also has a capacitor that keeps enough of a charge to maintain the display even if the batteries are dead and you unplug it from the wall to adjust the settings...which you will probably have to do if you plug it in on a typical lower wall outlet since the display is kind of small.
Still, this is a good item and worth a look if you want to set up auto climate control in an area not covered.
summary: Great for regulating a room's temperature

reviewText: Came fast. Good quality.

"Danco 10672 Hydro Seat toilet flange repair kit."
My first impression upon opening the box was this flange repair kit looked to be well constructed with a blue powder coated steel support ring with integral neoprene rubber seal that extends down into your plumbing toilet connection.  The steel flange also has the stainless steel toilet mounting studs already attached in the proper position, which make lining up your toilet that much easier.  The steel flange needs to be oriented correctly for the flange to line up correctly with the toilet and the flange is stamped with the word "BACK" on it so you shouldn't have a problem.  The kit comes with mounting hardware (four 1-1/2" screws) to accommodate the installation of the flange to the floor and washers and nuts to be used to attach the toilet to the flange.  You still need to purchase a wax ring(s) to seal the flange kit to your old toilet flange, if your bathroom floor has been built up with new flooring and your current flange is below the floor surface level, you may need to use two wax seals to achieve a good seal.
The nice thing about this kit is you don't need to use another wax ring to make a seal between the toilet and the Danco Flange repair kit, because of the built in neoprene rubber seal.  This allows you to remove and reinstall the toilet in the future without having to deal with the messy wax rings anymore.
After installing this kit, the toilet seems more stable and doesn't wobble at all and best of all the installation appears to be leak free!  I would recommend this flange repair kit to anyone that has a broken/damaged toilet flange, a flange that is recessed below floor level, or toilet that wobbles due to a loose plumbing flange.  If your toilet has been leaking for quite some time and the floor has become rotted, you'll need to replace the rotted wood first, because the flange repair kit needs to be mounted securely to the floor for it to work properly.
summary: Danco 10672 HydroSeat Toilet Flange repair kit.

reviewText:
I am a huge fan of solar lights.  I leave them up all year long.  They have survived heavy down pours to several feet of snow and keep on twinkling.  These ADDLON Solar LED string lights have joined my other string of lights on my deck making it an energy efficient way to add lighting to the stairs and deck leading to our French door entrance to our home.

The solar panel need to get at least 6 to 8 hours of direct sunlight to have a full charge, so make sure to place the solar panel in an area where it will face the sun directly to get amble amount of sunlight.  they will automatically turn on at night and turn off at daylight or when the power is drained.

Has 8 different lighting modes which you can cycle through by the MODE button on the back of the solar panel.

Also can be used indoors if you have a window that gets direct sunlight for at least 6 hours of the day.  Just place the solar panel on the inside window sill facing outwards.

Disclaimer:  Product sample provided for free or discounted for an honest unbiased review with no means of payment or incentives offered in exchange.
summary: Energy efficient lighting and so pretty

reviewText: Love them!

This is a nice, simple decoration for a space themed bedroom, or maybe a classroom.  It's a modified wall clock with a picture of the Earth (or more accurately, North and Central America, with a chunk of South America thrown in) that lights up a bit.  It doesn't actually function as a clock, just a light show.

My take is that it's nothing special, but my three year old son is going ape over it!  He loves clicking the remote control.  (I love the automatic 30minute timer so it doesn't kill the batteries once he falls asleep!)

For what it is, it's nice, and done well for a reasonable quality made-in-China low(er) price toy...  I'm not sure how much it's worth to you, but my wife and I both felt that the list price was too high and that the Amazon discounted price was at the top end of what we would pay.  This is one of those toys where I would not be surprised to find at a discount store with a damaged box at half the Amazon price... But that at the "bargain" price, we would love it!!!

These are really great lanterns to have around. My first exposure to this type lantern was with the Etekcity brand a couple years ago. Now there are more brand names of this same lantern than you can count. Regardless of the name, they all seem to do pretty much the same. The exception with these over my Etekcity, and more recent purchase of Beastron brand at two for $15.95 is this. The lights themselves are identical in style and brightness or lumens, and use the same type double A batteries, 3 each.  This 6 pack comes without batteries. But they have two features the others don't. One, a magnetic bottom, and two a hook on the bottom that flips out for hanging the lantern. And the three magnets on the bottom are strong enough to hold this lantern to any metallic object quite well. So it's a matter of economics ($6.16 per)  and features as to whether you determine this to be a value. You'll need 18 Double A (AA) batteries from the start. On top of the cost of the lantern. But the new features give you some additional ways in using these lanterns. Which in my opinion makes them a good buy. I would recommend using good alkaline batteries. And on that subject, although I have always used Coppertops. I tried Amazon Basics batteries which are by far cheaper. Although the shelf life isn't as long, they seem to work quite well. So you may take that into consideration as well. But I can definitely recommend this lantern. They are very bright. The more you pull the lantern up from the casing, the brighter the light. If you want it dimmer, just push it back into the casing. Hopefully the pictures will tell the story..
summary: As good as all the rest.. just buy batteries.

I thought I was purchasing a true swag lamp that could be plugged in. Instead, I'll have to have an expensive electrician wire it up. The ad was misleading!  (The lamp is pretty.)

Disclosure - product received at no charge in exchange for review.

A relation simple design makes for a nice product. A battery pack holding 3 AA batteries (not included) wired to a string of lights starting about 11" from the battery pack. Each light is in a globe made of translucent white plastic. Connected with thin, clear sheathed wire (~20-22 gauge). Nothing is replaceable or disconnectable but the batteries. No searching for that one bad bulb that keeps everything from working (like those Christmas lights).

I tested out how long the batteries last by inserting 3 rechargeable batteries. After a week they were still glowing. I'd expect alkaline batteries to slowly start to dim after a few days of constant use, where rechargeables usually die quickly when they run down.

There is a switch that lets you set them for off, on, or flashing (or more like seizure inducing).

The description clearly indicates these lights are not waterproof. However, if you got caught in a brief or light rain, they'd likely survive. You could also, with a bit of effort and a tube of silicone, seal each globe and put the battery pack in a Zip-loc bag and make these light very weather resistant. At least they're honest and don't claim to be waterproof as long as you don't expose them to water.

Inserting the batteries the first time can be tricky. But once you figure out how the top slides off, it's no problem.

These are not expensive appearing lights. There are no mold seams on the globes. But each has a collar into which the bulbs are pressed with a drop of glue. For the price though, they're quite a nice value. With a little ingenuity, you can find lots of uses beyond just a string of lights with a bulb every 4".

So, why not 5 stars?  As a longtime Amazon shopper, I've come to distrust any review with a 5 star rating that contains the words 'free sample' or 'honest and unbiased', and disregard them. So, think 4 1/2 stars, rounded down.

Thanks for reading.
summary: A safe, efficient string of lights

reviewText:
I'm a little torn over these lights.  They really are a warm white and look lovely when they're on.  But they suck up so much battery power that the lights begin to dim after six or eight hours of use.  After a rest they'll come on at almost full power but they dim more quickly with each use.  That seems like heavy battery use to me.  I'm not sure they're really worth the sheer number of AA batteries I used to keep the string working through the holidays.  LEDs are supposed to save energy, not suck it up.

Still... they are awfully pretty, and since it's genuinely difficult to find a true warm white LCD light that doesn't make your decor look institutional, I'm going middle-of-the-road here and giving them three stars.  I may try rechargeables with them next year and see if I feel any better about them.
summary: Pretty but maybe not worth the number of batteries they require

Great knee protection, but the buckles break and the elastic deforms quickly.  After my knee replacement, I was told I would be lucky if I could get back on my knees again, because the pain would be too bad.  Not so with these pads.  My work requires me to be on my knees in some pretty rough, dirty places, and these pads protect them wonderfully.  They support the bone lower leg bone and keep most of the weight off the knee itself.  I get a pair for each of my employees, simply to reduce the wear and tear and any injuries they might get.  The only problem I have with them - and the reason they don't get 5-starsm- is that the buckles break, and the elastic deforms (permanently stretches) way too soon.  When the buckle breaks, you have to thread the elastic band through a cinch slot (takes a lot of time, especially when wet, to say nothing of when it is cold), and when the elastic deforms, you have to replace it.  Unfortunately, i have not been able to find replacements for them.  If the company can solve these two problems, these would be the best things since sliced bread!!

reviewText: ... because they are being sold as protective eyewear. Unfortunately, if you were to wear these while weed wacking, chainsawing, lawn mowing, or any other -ing that throws small items towards your face, you would end up with some in your eye(s) because the lenses do not touch the cheek, by several millimeters! Me? When I put on a pair of protective eyewear, well I want to be protected. I would use MSA Safety Works 817691 Over Economical Safety Glasses, Clear or DEWALT DPG82-11C Concealer Clear Anti-Fog Dual Mold Safety Goggle, neither of which cost more than $15!!! So, let's recap: -Safety? Not much. But if you just want to get around a requirement to wear safety eyewear and look good while cheating, these are acceptable. -Photochromic? Yep. The change is imperceptible speed-wise, but it does occur and gets fairly dark in direct sun, so if you want a pair of pretty good looking sunglasses, these are acceptable. -Functionality? Hmmm. PROS: Light (very), Photochromic, comfortable fit. CONS: Not safe.

reviewText:
I live in a small condo by myself, yet only accumulate the same amount of dust as a small family of 3. I do have dust allergies, but having subjected myself to it in such a confined space, they've lessened. So when I got this I was highly skeptical that it would work, let's just say within two days of using it, I had to clean the back of it already. First off that's a gross testament to how dusty my house gets, and second to how well it traps it.

Pros:
-Well Designed- This thing covers every intake aspect without hindering/covering output. Whomever designed this was rather intelligent, it's stupidly simple, but 100% effective. NOTE: It does cut output power by 10%, but that's to be expected when you cover the intake end.
-Rather effective*- rather quickly was I able to see visible signs of effectivity.

Cons:
-Now this is a rough one, and just a personal one, I wish the back was a lighter color, so it is easier to see its effect. I get that most people don't want that, especially when they might be entertaining guests, and then there is also the potential staining, I get why you did it, but again, it's a personal issue.

NOTES:
This thing is an additive, so the thing that it's adding too determines how well it works. I have a pretty decent oscillating fan. It's pretty powerful and can really cool a large ~300-400 sq ft room effectively. This also works better when you have your fan in oscillation mode (turning back and forth).

With the success I've had with this one, I'm more than inclined to buy their boxed fan version.

Good product but poor manual and no way to calibrate! This is a really good laser tape yet I am giving two stars for several reasons. It works great for anything over 20" with 1/16" accuracy. You can do many calculations. Mine came calibrated and works great for now but I followed the manual and could not calibrate. Their instruction amounts to jack squad. It works for now but the calibration can go off if you drop it or if there is sudden temperature change. Then what do you do? I cannot depend on it if I am measuring it for expensive crown moulding if there is no way for me to calibrate. Recently we remodeled a bathroom, with nice fixtures and nice tiles.  I was dissatisfied with the light cast by the floodlight located in the recessed can above the wash basin.  After trying four different floodlight bulbs, I came to the following conclusions.

[1]  Dispersion angle of the light beam is very important

In my opinion, my bathroom looks much better when the beam dispersion angle of the floodlight leaves the walls above waist level in relatively low light, and the wall sections below waist level in a relatively bright light. In the case of my bathroom, I found that the ideal beam angle to achieve this would be about 70 degrees (see Footnote 2 for the method to calculate beam angle).

The beam angles of the lights I tried are as follows:

== Polaroid (the light reviewed here):  About 65 degrees by my calculation

== Bioluz LED Br40 Smooth 17w 2700k 1400 Lumens --  110 degree angle, manufacturer's calculation.

== Philips model 429035, 3000K, 1200 lumens  .  25 degree angle stated in Amazon ad

== G7  Power Vegas BR40  .  180 degree beam angle.

Unfortunately, many manufacturers neglect to state beam angle.

[2] Lumens

I found that between 1200 and 1600 lumens gave pretty bright light.

[3] Kelvin color temperature

Light with Kelvin color temperatures between 2,700K and 3,000K is considered to be "warm".  Warm is more flattering to humans, and more pleasant.  I found that temps between 2700K and 3000K worked well for me. Quite possibly a bit higher up to 4000K would also work. See Wikipedia for discussion.

[4] The recessed overhead light does not properly illuminate the face of someone using the bathroom mirror.  To accomplish this, we installed an actor's style array of lights around the edges of the mirror.

/------------------------------------------------------------------

FOOTNOTE 1: PROS AND CONS OF POLAROID FLOODLIGHT

PROS:

(a) it is bright with 1600 lumens ;

(b) has a beam dispersion angle that is better for my purposes of illuminating my 5' x 8' bathroom

(c) has the best guarantee I have seen, 15 years;

(d) very important for my purposes, it has ventilation slots surrounding the light source, so that the exhaust fan which is part of the light fixture can draw more air out of the room (none of the other three bulbs I tested had this type of ventilation slot);

(e) it is rated as suitable for damp locations, which is exactly where the lamp will be located, in a recess in my bathroom ceiling.

CONS

None that I have yet identified.

/-------------------------------------

FOOTNOTE 2:  If you want the brightest part of the beam to cover the wall below waist height (about 30"), do the following measurements to find the correct beam angle: [a] Measure the distance between ceiling and waist height, and call it D1. So with a ceiling 96" from the floor, D1 will be 96"-30" or 66" (I assume a waist height of 30"). [b] Then measure the distance between the center of the light and the furthest wall, and call it D2.  [c] Then construct on graph paper a right angle triangle where D1 is the perpendicular side, and D2 is the side horizontal to the ground.  Then use a protractor to measure the angle at the top vertex of the triangle. And multiply that angle by two.  If you remember your trigonometry, you can do it that way too.
summary: Best floodlight out of 4 that I tried

So I bought this faucet and had it installed in my brand new renovated Kitchen. I actually really love it. It fits into a modern or a traditional kitchen. Here's why I am giving this a 3 star: The little button or piece that indicated Hot & Cold (i.e. Red and Blue color dot right at the lever) came off. For the amount of money I spent on this and the first week it's installed and it comes off. It is absolutely not ok.

I pushed it back in but it keeps popping back off. If you guys know how to fix it without tearing the whole thing apart, please tell me!

Apart from that the flow of the water is pretty good. You have to toggle the switch on and off for spray to regular flow. I wish this came with the soap dispenser like it's sold everywhere else. I had to buy that separately for ~$30.

Overall, I would say, BUY IT! But Keep your receipt and report issues right away. I am hoping Delta contacts me and tells me how they'll fix this.
summary: Love the design! BUT Buyer be aware!

For the price this is an excellent tool. I used it with a few thousand 2" and 3" nails over the course of a couple weeks working on an outbuilding and had no performance problems. The magazine feed loads easily and switching nail sizes was quicker and easier than with coil based systems.

It is surprisingly light weight, but is free from any fragile looking plastic parts that seem common on <$300 pneumatic tools.  The carry case, while large, is of good quality.

Depth adjust worked well and I had no feed failures, jams or other problems.  Compared to the price of renting a similar tool, you easily come out money ahead buying this one after just one or two small projects.

I'd definitely purchase it again if I ever had the need.
summary: Great performance, unbeatable price, zero problems after a couple weeks of use.

reviewText: This is a nice LED lantern that uses 4 of the larger "C" size batteries. With the batteries in, the lamp is a lot heavier as you would expect, otherwise it's fairly light since it is made mostly of plastic. There are 4 modes: on with warm light (they call it moonlight), off, on with cool bluish light (they call it daylight), and motion activated with cool bluish light. Unfortunately there is no way to use the warm light with the motion detection. The lantern has a nice metal loop at the top so you can hang it. I can see it used for emergencies or for everyday use, like near some stairs or in a bathroom with it set to use the motion detection. It also won't turn on if there's already enough light, and that will extend the battery life. This is a decent (but not exceptional) lantern but I like this one even better: Ivation 6-LED Battery Operated Motion Sensing Table Lamp - Multi Zone Light: Body Only, Shade Only, or Both Body & Shade - can Also Light Continuously Overall 4 stars. NOTE: I was sent a free product sample for review. I was not paid or told what to write.
summary: Good LED lantern with two light color options (warm & cool)

I had never used a bidet before I bought and installed this one and I will never be without a bidet again. Using the bidet gives me a very fresh feeling.
