I had back surgery last Fall and it would have made things a lot easier during the early days of my recovery if I had this then.

Update 12/2/2016: I really liked this bidet until the nozzles started sticking in the down position after just a few months. The Luxe people were very nice and replaced that unit with a new one. But, unfortunately, the new one started having the same problem in just a few months. (I hate having to turn on the light in the middle of the night to find the nozzle and push it back up before I can flush.)
I have a water softener so there was not calcium build-up on the nozzle. I put a bidet filter in the line just in case the city's sand filters were letting enough sand through to stick the mechanism. No luck. Still got stuck. So I just bought a bidet attachment with a removable/replaceable nozzle.

Like most folks, I have been using the wet sponge for cleaning my soldering iron tips.  The thermal shock on the tip each time it is cleaned can interfere with your heat levels on basic soldering irons.  Plus, you need to keep the sponge wet (but not too wet) as you work.

After all the other positive reviews, I figured 'why not?'.  Why did I not get this earlier?  It really works well - much better than the sponge.

The unit is very light, so like some other reviewers I popped it open and dumped a few metal screws and washers until it 'felt about right' weight wise. I did not want it to move at all when used.  Other folks have used sand for weight.  The extra weight is not absolutely necessary, but it seems to 'complete' the unit for me.

I cannot imagine using anything else for cleaning a hot soldering iron tip now.
summary: If you solder - you really will love this.

Ok, before I bought this knife, I did some research and compared it to a couple of different knives. Basically what I was looking for is a knife that has the following:

One hand open/closing blade
saw
Scissors
Bottle/Can Openers
Flat and Phillips screw drivers
Belt Clip
Lanyard loop
Less than 4inches closed

After searching and searching, I realized that my dream knife didn't exist. SO I had to compromise. This was my compromise. It doesn't have the scissors, belt clip and is not less than 4 inches closed, but it does have Saw, Bottle/Can opener, lanyard loop and the screwdrivers so it's not a bad compromise. My problem with the knife is the engineering of it. The thumb lock-release for the main blade is designed for a left handed user. I knew this before I purchased, but I didn't think it was going to be that much of an issue. Sadly, I was wrong. The lock requires an immense amount of force which intern gives me a blister on thumb. Surely I could put the knife in my left hand, but if I had two free hands I wouldn't need the one handed open and close. The most aggravating part of this is, is that there is plenty of room to put the lock on the other side and just move the knife. It would seem that the only reason they did this was so that the bottle opener/flat blade screw driver could lock, which in my opinion is stupid since the Phillips driver doesn't lock. My other gripe is that the knife is huge in my hands. I am 5'10", 180lbs, and I have what most glove makers would say medium sized hands and this thing feels like a mini K-bar knife in my hand. Though this is easy to look past, what is not easy to look past is that I intended this to be a Every Day Carry (EDC) Knife but if I put this in the same pocket as my keys I have no room for anything else, and since there is no belt clip, it MUST go in my pocket or dangled on my hip like a fish on a hook.

The things I do like and love about Victoronox knives this knife has though. The blade is a smooth and sharp and easy to resharpen, the construction feels very solid and the knife doesn't look like I'm trying to survive out in the wild for months. The scales are made of what feels like a composite ABS which I think is fantastic. And with all these combined I have no doubt that the knife will never fail me.

With all that said, I would not recommend this knife to someone searching for the same thing. I would recommend a Leatherman Wave (which I own) first because it is smaller and has all the features I was looking for. The only reason I wanted a new knife is that my leatherman is somewhat heavy to carry around and I wanted a cheaper knife in my pocket just in case I ever lose it. Other than that, it's a FANTASTIC knife.

Anyways that is my review, as always you can ask me any questions you'd like I'll do my best to answer. Thanks

This is my first clamp meter. Before I got this meter I've always just had plain multimeters. Which, to be honest, have always been sufficient for me given that I'm not an electrician. However, I decided to get this clamp meter because even though I may not use it very frequently, when needed, the ability to instantly/easily test a wire for current is a really great added feature to have. Even for the non-electrician.

This particular clamp meter has a very long list of functions and practical uses that will certainly be more than sufficient for the average user. A few things I particularly like about this meter are the dual display, its ability to test diodes, the temperature probe and its hold and maximum reading functions.

I've had this multimeter for almost a month now, and as such I've tested most of its functions, and so far they are all working without issue. I really don't have any complaints about this multimeter, but if an issue arises or becomes apparent, I'll be sure to update this review.

Now, while this certainly isn't the cheapest clamp meter out there, Amprobe is a quality brand, and this is a much better than average meter. It's well-designed and seems really well-made. It's function-rich, and as such it performs a LOT of tasks. I'm sure it will test/troubleshoot any electrical issue I might have, and provide me with years of trouble-free use. Consequently, I highly recommend this clamp meter. I hope this review was helpful to you.
summary: A Very Good Function-Rich Clamp Meter

reviewText: My mom loves it! She likes the elegant look of the product and it fits perfectly in her bathroom.

For the money, these are fine.  They're fairly cheaply made, and while they don't give off huge amounts of light, when you use them as I am doing, as under cabinet lights in the kitchen, they serve their purpose.

Please do take the instructions and warnings in the product listing seriously.  Be sure you want a light in a certain spot before you stick it on something because these things are NOT repositionable.  However, If you do have a change of heart, they're light enough that you could probably replace the adhesive with some velcro.  Do they stick?  I haven't had a problem, but then the underside of my kitchen cabinets is rough, and adhesives are more likely to stick to something that's a bit rough.  I'm not sure they'd be quite as effective on a slick surface, but I  could be wrong.

When you insert the batteries, you may find that the contacts have been pushed upwards, and are preventing the cover from being replaced.  Just take the battery out, push the metal contact downward gently, and replace the battery.  It's not difficult.

Mine seem to be burning away happily.  Given the price, if I get a year or two out of them, I'll be happy.  If you want something stronger, prettier or more flexible, look elsewhere.  But for dark corners and a bit of extra task lighting, these are just fine.

This shower arm has great water flow.  What I don't get is why it goes out so far with so little rise.  If you already have a shower arm at a height you like, but want a set-up for a rain showerhead, then go for it.  I read reviews and people raved about how much higher their showerhead was, but this was not the case for me.  Granted, by shower was built for hobbits and the shower head was too low for me at 5'6, but I was disappointed that this wasn't the shower arm I was looking for after reading all of the great reviews.

I opted for an S curve shower arm and it was perfect!  I bought it locally, so I'm not sure if you can find the exact one on here.

When the stuff actually exits the can, it's fine. Maybe great. I wouldn't know. Every can I ordered (which I didn't use in time to return) ended up clogging almost immediately. The tip wasn't clogged, either - it was something else down in the bowels of the can. The first time this happened I assumed the solids didn't mix sufficiently so I shook the second can for a solid 4 or 5 minutes (in all directions, etc). No difference. Third can, same thing.

I am very happy with this headlamp. I ended up returning the same headlamp but Coral in color just days prior because I could not get the light to illuminate after I had charged it for approximately 4-hours. The problem, which was not mentioned in the package insert, was a thin piece of clear plastic that was placed between the battery contacts and the light to prevent battery discharge. After close inspection, I realized the the plastic had to be removed for the light to function.
This headlamp has a very comfortable headband and fits great. The Reactive Lighting Technology dims the light automatically when you get close to objects and does not waste light or battery power. I own both the NITECORE HC50 and HC90 headlamps. I love the Petzi Tikka RXP and the NITECORE headlamps equally. I would suggest the Petzi for light weight and comfort. You might forget the Petzi was placed on your head it is so comfortable; and the NITECORE(s), which are pretty comfortable as well, for power/maximum illumination.
I am happy that these headlamp manufactures are producing quality, competitive, products that are durable, functional, and fun to own and talk about.
Again, do not forget to remove the clear plastic strip sandwiched between the battery and the bulb contacts! Otherwise, the light will not illuminate.

Let me make this short.  Screw Drivers are good, the pliers us cheap metal to metal spring action that NEVER stays aligned and will end up frustrating you.  Get a set of pliers that have a true spring between them and use hardened steel.
summary: Screw Drivers pass, pliers are junk.

reviewText: Matches the Mahindra paint

This flashlight from INGEAR lives up to claims made in the retail material -- it is sturdy (anodized aluminum construction), bright (95 lumens) and very portable (3.5 inches long x 3/4 inch wide and weighing in at just 2.3 ounces). It runs on one AA battery (not included) and claims to be able to run continuously on one battery for 2 - 4 hours. That's all good!

What sets this light apart from others is its strong magnetic end. You can (and we have) turn this light on and stick it under the hood of your car to shine down on wherever you need... like the radiator, to check the fluid level. I like that innovation a lot.

What might be somewhat problematic is the way you turn this flashlight on and off; you screw the lens-end on tightly and, once tightened, the flashlight goes into always-on mode. When done using the flashlight, you unscrew the lens-end until the light goes off and it stays off. If being able to turn your flashlight on & off quickly and easily is not high on your priority list, then this is not an issue for you. Since it turns on in this manner, there are no alternate operating modes (no S.O.S, strobe, or low beam settings), just full-on 95 lumens or full-off dark.

That said, I do believe that this light produces the advertized 95 lumens as it is fairly bright, and the magnets worked exceedingly well in every place we tested it (under our Jeep's hood, on the refrigerator, etc...) Those are fairly big pluses, though their values needs to be weighed in comparison to the significant selling price.

This headlight unit comes packaged in a wonderful retail box, complete with foam inserts to protect it during shipping. It arrived in perfect condition; all we had to do was take it out of the box, put the battery in, and screw the lens tightly to turn it on.

The retail information states that this unit is covered by INGEAR's "1 YEAR WARRANTY & 24/7 CUSTOMER SUPPORT!", so if an issue arises during that period I will return here to update the review and let you know what the issue was and how resolution was handled. I did receive this LED flashlight gratis from the seller and put it to use to objectively find out how well it performed. My statements here reflect that testing.

If you are looking for a very portable flashlight of this style, size, 95 lumens power, on & off mechanism and price, for use similar to what I have described above, then this one works well and is quite small and bright, so it might be just what you are looking for.

Go for it.
summary: INGEAR LED Flashlight - CREE Q3 95 Lumens - Sturdy - Magnetic end - Bright

I have used this product, and thought it was OK until I used ZRC cold galvanizing.  There is no comparison.  The Rustoleum product is very runny and deposits very little actual zinc on the surface.  It ends up soft and easily scratched.  I used it on my chain link fence (after cleaning for good adhesion) but every two years or so I had to respray as rust started showing again.

When I decided to rebuild my galvanized boat trailer I knew I need a better cold galvanizing compound.  After lots of research I found ZRC.  This stuff is great and has lasted.  The can is very heavy as 95% of the contents is zinc.  It is very hard after drying and no scratch problems.  It also comes in bright new galvanized finish or old dull galvanized finish.  Of course I choose old.  It also comes in a spray.

The Rustoleum product is OK if all you require is a fairly temporary coating that won't need to take any abuse, but it's a far cry from a quality cold galvanizing.

Rustoleum also makes a quart size in a brush/roller/spray on version, which is also 95% zinc.  But it is not nearly as user friendly as the ZRC quart product. ZRC covers better, thicker, and adheres better.
summary: It ends up soft and easily scratched. I used it on my chain link ...

This daylight LED recessed lighting kit is an excellent product. It is made of high quality material, looks and feels heavy duty and durable, its not flimsy at all like many other competitors. By comparing with my other ceiling recessed light fixtures, this LED light output is much brighter than CFL BR40 incandescent flood bulb.

This LED light turns on instantly to the max brightness level, not like my old CFL BR40 bulb which slowly reaches to the brightest level. When switching off this LED light, it turn off instantly, there is no afterglow. Also, this LED light is dimmable so it won't flicker or shutoff down or make buzz noise at low or high light level settings on your dimmer switch.

This LED retrofit module replaced my old CFL BR40 incandescent flood bulb. This recessed lighting kit fitted perfectly into 6 ceiling recessed lighting trim as you can see in attached picture. The kit comes with E26 base adapter so you don't have to rewire to connect new LED module, simply screw in the E26 adapter to the old light bulb socket then connect the adapter to the LED modular light connector.

Here are simple and easy to follow Installation steps for anyone needing it:
1. Turn off the power before installation
2. Unscrew and take off the old bulb
3. Remove the existing baffle trim
4. Screw in the E26 socket adapter into the E26 socket,
5. Connect the LED modular light connector to E26 adapter
6. Turn the power on to test if LED light turns on. Turn off the power again to continue with next step
7. Compress the spring clips on the LED light module and insert into the ears on the inside of the recessed can housing (see attached picture)
8.  Push the LED light module into the recessed can housing until the trim is flush with the ceiling surface.

I highly recommend these lights to anyone looking for a bright daylight LED replacement in the 5000k color range, just be aware that it is DAYLIGHT bright since so many of us are accustomed to a yellowish incandescent bulb.

The product arrived just as described, in a timely manner, was packaged perfectly, and in excellent condition.

This product was provided at a discounted price or free in exchange for my honest review. This is not a paid review. My opinions are entirely my own and in no way did the discounted price influence my review of this product.

 Please let me know by leaving a comment below if you found this review not helpful at all so I can assist you better or provide better details about the product. Thank you for reading my review.

Works great. I had to disassemble mine to remove the clamp and replace it with bracket. To do that, I had to unscrew every part there was and desolder the wires from the little board. With the bracket, I secured this lamp to the back of the bed, because there are no clamp wide enough to clamp the bed head board. It was a simple right angle bracket from home depot, in which I drilled one more hole.

In doing this I got to see the inside of this lamp. The voltage board is a typical chinese production, and it doesn't look like it is going to last too long. The rest of the components are not too bad and will probably be fine for a long while. The goose neck is strong and tight.

I recommend this lamp for those DIY-ers who can't quite find the one they want, as this will be a good test and it may be re-done differently.

Easy to install, charges quickly and supports rapid charging. Most importantly, it's UL certified! Don't waste your money and put yourself and/or your family at risk by buying a cheaper one that's not UL certified. Leviton is a trusted name. Forget the other cheap Chinese junk that'll burn your house down.
summary: Great solution to a common problem

We used the bulb in an application they had suggested in their marketing with no warnings about compatibility issues. The product and its misleading description are one-star. I bought this Dremel because it is the only one that works with Dremel's new multisaw attachment.  With that attachment, which is sold separately, you can use it like a miniature reciprocating saw (Sawzall).  Just pop any "T" or "U" shaped jigsaw blade in, and you're in business.  I don't know of another tool that can be used in this way, and for that reason and that reason alone this Dremel is worth owning.

I already own another multiple-speed Dremel, and I thought I'd sell it once I bought this.  But I'm keeping both because this new Dremel simply feels cheap and poorly made.  It seems like its plastic case is flimsier and it doesn't feel as balanced when it's operating.  It certainly isn't ergonomic.  Any Dremel user who buys this latest model will instantly notice the drop-off in quality.

On the good side, the multisaw attachment works well and the molded plastic case is designed to hold the Dremel, the multisaw and planer attachments, jigsaw blades, the included circle cutter and flex shaft.  The kit also includes two bit sets that lock onto the top of the case, with room for two more on the sides.

There's no way I can tell if this Dremel will last.  I've put a pretty good load on the motor, and it hasn't failed.  But I think that if I drop it more than a few feet onto a hard surface, it will break.  The shaft lock button feels particularly cheap and uncertain.  I expect it to break first.

Despite all my concerns I'm keeping this Dremel.  But I'll only use it when I need the multisaw or planer attachment (the planer attachment must be purchased separately...it only comes with the higher-priced kit).  Any other time I'll use my other Dremel (model no. 3956-02).

It's extremely unfortunate that at the same time it has chosen to make the most versatile Dremel yet, the company also decided to cut corners on quality.  Dremel doubtlessly wanted to keep the price down on this unit, but in doing so they've produced a multi-function tool that feels like a toy.
summary: A tool that feels like a toy...

My house uses forced air for heating. The disadvantage of such a system is that it distributes the dust in the air everywhere in the house. However, it is supposed to be possible to filter out the dust. Over the years, I have steadily increased the quality of the filter that I use for my forced air heating system. However, until now I have not noticed any obvious difference in my allergic reactions that seem to start with the heating season.

There are cats in my house. I have read that cat dander, tiny flakes of cat skin shed by the cats, is five times smaller than household dust particles. It stays in the air much longer than ordinary dust before it settles. Because of its small size it requires a more efficient filter to get it out of the air.

Until three years ago, I used of variety of filters with mixed results. However, then I started using the 3M Advanced Allergen Filters, the ones in the blue wrapper. These have a 3M Microparticle Performance Rating of 1500, and a MERV rating of 12.

MERV stands for Minimum Efficiency Reporting Value produced from a test designed by the American Society of Heating, Refrigerating and Air Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE). A higher MERV rating indicates better filter performance.

3M uses particle data between 0.3 and 1.0 micron size to calculate a Microparticle Performance Rating or MPR. The higher the MPR, the better the filter. However, higher rated filters cost more.

Here are some of the Filtrete filters offered by 3M:

Dust & Pollen Filter, Microparticle Performance Rating 600,
MERV rating of 8
Micro Allergen Filter, Microparticle Performance Rating 1000,
MERV rating of 11
Ultra Allergen Filter, Microparticle Performance Rating 1250,
MERV rating of 11
Advanced Allergen Filter, Microparticle Performance Rating 1500,
MERV rating of 12
Ultimate Allergen Filter, Microparticle Performance Rating 1900,
MERV rating of 13.

The difference made by the Advanced filter was immediately obvious. My running nose stopped running. I assume that the new Advanced filters must be taking out more of the dust in the air including the cat dander. I have not noticed a change in the speed of the circulated air.

More recently, I have started using the newer Ultimate filter. It works better than the Advanced filter. The additional cost of the filter is worth it if you have allergies or pets. However, if you are happy with a lower-rated and lower-cost filter, then continue using that one.

I suggest that you check Amazon and vendors on the web to get the best price.

Ive always wanted some crowfoot wrenches, but could never justify the price for something I knew would not get used often.  Most other crowfoots must actually be made from trained crows, and training crows must be expensive, because they always seem very expensive.  Imagine my delight when I saw these shiny things for only $14.  Heck, for 14 bucks they could be made out of glue and tissue paper and Id probably still buy them just to give them a try.  I bought both the SAE and Metric sets without hesitation.

They arrived very well polished, they look like the shiniest tools in my collection (maybe because they have so much flat surface area) and they come with your typical rail to hold them all together.  The first thing I wanted to do was try them out and see if under that fancy, shiny chrome plating was indeed pressed glue and tissue paper so I used them to take off a brake caliper mounting boltit worked like a charm.

It does drive me bonkers that it skips sizes.  Im convinced that some manufacturers like to say 10 piece socket set, sizes from 6mm to 34mm! and figure the buyer won't notice that there has to be some missing sizes in there somewhere.  But I digress, Im sure they have some marketing information and sales numbers to justify making sets that skip sizes, but it just makes my head hurt.  Like that guy on the Discovery Channel, I don't want to say it was aliensbut it was aliens.  The one star I took away was because of this.

Overall, Im very pleased with my purchase.  I know these won't get used often, but when Im in that situation where a crowfoot makes the job so much easier, Ill smile.  And if the size I need is one thats not in this kit, Ill cry.

FYIDid you know that the Corvidae bird family (which includes crows, magpies, and ravens) are the smartest birds in the world?  Recent studies have shown they can count, can remember a humans face, and have even been seen making simple tools.  Hmmm, maybe they did make these wrenches

The good ... Hot and cold water lines are braided stainless steel. These are far easier to connect than solid copper because it is easier to pull them to the side and connect to your water lines coming from the wall. The line for the faucet is a braided nylon which looks reasonable to protect the line in the long run. The unit has a flow-timer which will shutoff the water after 3 minutes of no motion.

The bad ... Although it has a relatively heavy weight to pull the head back in after releasing (the spray head) it does seem to get tangled up in other water lines (the supply lines) below the counter when I pull it out all of the way. I realize the amount of space will vary from one installation to another, but my installing isn't atypical in that there is limited space between a deep sink and the back of the cabinet/wall. I've seen this with other pull-outs. The one way to really avoid this is when you have a corner install with lots of space. The unit comes with a flow-meter/valve which does the auto shut-off. This is good -- but the problem is that it is another device/black box to have to install. It is about 3/4" to 1" thick and about or just less than 6" x 4 1/2". You will need to find a place to mount this, I'd suggest the back wall or cabinet wall.

I bought several of these. Some from Amazon, some from Ebay. All but one died within a month. Luckily I am an electrical engineer. After taking the lights apart I found that there was not a sufficient amount of thermal grease between the LED cluster and the base. Also, there should be 4 screws holding the LED in place. Some of my light fixtures only had 2. Another problem is that the holes that were drilled and tap'd for these 4 screws are not deep enough. The screws bottom out before they apply proper pressure on the LED. The major cause for these lights to keep failing is improper heat transfer. Excessive heat kills LED's every time.
If you go to Ebay, and do a search for "100W White High Power LED Panel 9000LM 100 Watt Lamp Light" you will find the actual LED clusters. Buy these. Only $8, what a deal!
Then go get yourself some high quality thermal heat-sink grease. Remove the old LED cluster, and unsolder the wires. Clean off the old thermal grease. Without the LED in place, screw in the 4 screws to make sure they go all the way in without bottoming out. If they don't, either get shorter screws, or drill and tap deeper holes, and get new screws to match your new thread. Make sure both surfaces, (LED & Light base), are clean and smooth. Spread a thick layer of new thermal grease onto the LED and install with the 4 screws, nice and tight! Clean off excess thermal grease. Solder on the wires, (there is a + & - on the LED cluster), and you are finished. Really not that difficult. Hopefully you did not throw away your bad light fixtures before you read this:)

Kohler is known for making some excellent products! Unfortunately this Kohler K-4986-7 Cachet Nightlight toilet is not one of them. The main issue is the hinge which also contains the light on the rear of the seat. It fails to remain secure to the seat. You can struggle  to get it in only to find that after one week or less it has disconnected to the toilet. I think personally this is a design flaw and the product was not tested long enough before it was marketed. The hinge on the rear of the seat is very tight in order to give the "quiet close" feature which prevents a slamming toilet seat and/or lid. Unfortunately this tight hinge "fights" the toilet brackets that hold the lid to the toilet itself with bolts. These brackets are flimsy plastic and they constantly come undone by simply snapping off when you move the seat up or down. The light was a great idea but who wants a toilet seat that is a hassle to keep on. Mine actually would come off and the light almost fell in the bowl water. Someone could actually get hurt if they sat on this when it was not connected and mine disconnected itself at least 15 times.
 I doubt this toilet  seat will be on the market in a years time because people are going to get hurt using this. Mine would be disconnected when I came home from work just laying on the rim unsecured. If you ever have guests using your bathroom are you going to warn them to be careful because that the toilet seat may come off ?What if you forget and they get hurt? This is not a worry you should have for a well made and well designed toilet seat which this is NOT.
The light is located in the rear of the seat in the moving hinge assembly. This is a terrible location for the light and is bound to fail and cause issues. In my opinion the light should have been located in the front of the seat and not part of the hinge in any way.
This is a product that you really can not evaluate until using it for a few weeks. Unfortunately many people write reviews within a day or two of receiving a product which in my opinion accounts for the numerous positive reviews for this flawed toilet seat. This toilet seat is really bad and after about a week, maybe two, you will realize that the nightlight is never going to last. The light will often become disconnected like the seat and once it falls into the bowl it is ruined and no good. Even if you avoid letting the night light fall into the bowl water it is still going to get wet. How are you going to clean the seat and toilet and keep moisture out of the nightlight? You can not unless you remove the light every time. It is guaranteed that the night light will get wet because the light assembly is not waterproof or watertight.
 Once your light no longer works why would you even buy this expensive toilet seat ? It is cheap plastic with really cheap plastic flimsy hinges and a night light that will fail you in a short time.
Novelties can be fun such as a night light in your toilet seat. They can even be useful if they work. Once the novelty of this night light toilet seat wears off you realize you have an unsafe product that could injure a person and a light that is not designed to last very long.
Just so readers know I am not the type of person who likes to return products. I looked at my purchase history with Amazon and saw that I have made one return in my past 100 purchases over 6 months. Toilet seats are not an item you normally want to return. However I was so bothered by the fact that Kohler( normally a company with great products) would market a toilet seat as flawed and dangerous as this seat to the public that returning it seemed the only way to get the message to Kohler--"Your toilet seat is JUNK--pull it off the market and completely redesign it."  Three weeks with this miserable seat was enough for me and I returned mine to Amazon.
summary: A Flawed Design and an UnSafe Product !

reviewText: My husband loved this so much, this was the second one that he purchased.

This is a solid chunk of metal.  I wanted a small unit that runs on a AA battery instead of a set of button batteries.  It has a pocket clip which is actually usable.  The clips on some lights are too loose, no grip.  The clip on the Streamlite Keymate is so tight that you have to force it open.  The light turns on by screwing down the end cap (not the head like other small flashlights).  This is yet another light that has the direction wrong.  It's on when screwed down tight.  It's off when loosened.  If you don't loosen it enough, it will turn on accidentally if pressed.  Fortunately, the thread has a long travel, so you can safely loosen it a lot.  It takes 10 and a half turns for the cap to screw off, so you don't need to worry about it accidentally falling off.  You can signal by first screwing the cap all the way down and then loosening it until the light just goes out.  The contacts are spring-loaded, so you can signal by repeatedly pushing and releasing the end cap (simulates a tail cap switch).  The beam is diffuse and even, with a cold bluish hue.

The big neg?  My small Streamlight Nano and Keymate, which both run on button batteries, are brighter.  Unlike other reviews here, I find the light too dim.

Note added:  I've now purchased other small LED flashlights.  One of the reasons this unit is not as bright is because there is no reflector bowl or lens.  The LED is exposed and recessed into a bowl which is painted all black.  If you get dirt on the LED, it's hard to wipe off (and you may scratch it up).  Because there is no reflector, lens, or on/off switch, it is more compact than other 1-AA flashlights.

I purchased  this multipack hoping that it would make life easier to just grab one from the shelf instead of having to go buy one every couple months.  First appearances were that it was not a full inch thick but that by itself doesn't make it bad.  Also it's not a true fit.  I ordered 20 x 20 and it's more like 19.5 by 19.5 which means as others have written the filter is constantly plopping down and sucking back into place every time the fan engages in my attic.  This also was not a huge deal to me since when it was sucked into place I assumed it was a pretty good seal.  The main reason I give this filter 1 star is because it is so restrictive.  My house is only 1 year old and we have the furnace in the attic and central air pump outside,  last summer we ran filtrete and kept the house super cool every day and every night with no problems.  Since switching to these filters I noticed it would take much longer for the thermostat to reach desired temp until one day my house would not even cool and we're not even to june yet.  Outside the line to my heat pump would often freeze up to solid ice and I read that was because of lack of air flow.  Last night I couldn't sleep from the heat and my AC not blowing cool air and I climbed up into the attic and took apart the furnace and found a block of ice.  These filters not only will not let my system cool but my energy bill also went up about 10 dollars a month when i switched to these from the system over working itself.  I hate to throw them away so i will probably save them for winter to use with heat mode only and go back to something else for summer.
summary: too loose a fit and doesn't flow air well

THE OTHER 10% IT TELLS ME THE DOOR  IS OPEN WHEN IT IS CLOSED.  I WAS GOING TO EXCHANGE IT A THIRD TIME FOR ONE MORE TRY BUT THEY REFUNDED MY MONEY SAYING THEY WERE OUT OF STOCK.  MAYBE I WILL TRY ONE MORE WHEN IT IS IN STOCK,  ORIGINAL REVIEW:  Well,the first one they sent me did not work reliably. So far this one is working correctly now, so time will tell.  I've only had it a week.  If your garage is some distance from your home or the signal has to go through obstacles then buy this one and not the Chamberlin.  I purchased the Chamberlin about two years ago and it was not reliable at all.  I finally disconnected it and threw it away.  My problem is obstacles.  My garage is in the basement, above that is six inches of steel reinforced concrete which was a patio over the garage.  We later added on a second floor and added one room downstairs over the garage (patio).  Our bedroom is above that.  Consequently the signal has to go through the concrete ceiling of the garage, through the ceiling of that 1st floor room and the floor of our bedroom.  Unfortunately the signal of the Chamberlin could not always penetrate to make it to the receiver.  This unit has a stronger signal which has no problem passing through those obstacles.  So if you need a unit with a stronger signal, buy this one not the Chamberlin.
summary: Buy this unit not the Chamberlin if you have a distance or obstacles. NO LUCK WITH THE SECOND ONE THEY SENT ME!.

Morever, the pleating on the filter is relatively tight, giving it a larger surface area on which to catch particles. The major brand sells for much more, so we are pleased with the purchase from a value standpoint.

Regardless, if you order this item, examine them immediately & be prepared to return for an undamaged item, perhaps more than once. That is what I had to do.

I do not have it in front of me at the moment (I'm at work).
There are several LCD bars ranging from dead to poor, to weak, to good.
(Again I believe)...Each range has about 4 or 5 bars within a group or 16 to 20 bars total.

Problem is with a fully charged "rechargable" the checker shows or highlight in the middle of the 'good'.  I also tested a battery that had been in a wall clock for over a year (clock was dead stopped) it read at top end of the weak or about 2-3 marks below the fully charged NiMH just now charged.

I suspect a brand new alkaline may be able to get a little higher than middle of the 'good' range.

Bottom line:
If you are using rechargables, do not buy the T-333.
If you are using alkaline, you will be able to detect brand new and not brand new.  There may be a subtle difference between used and dead.

The best tester for rechargable batteries which I got the same day as T-333 is the ZTS MINI BATTERY TESTER.

The best tester/charger which I also got the same day is the La Crosse BC900.

Also the following is what I've read, have not verified myself yet.
There are two types of NiMH batteries.

Very high capacity around 2600 maH.
These slowly lose there charge on the self.

The other type is pre-charged around 2000 maH
These hold there charge over a year self life.

Also Sanya enevelope or something like that are the ones to get.
So far so good.

Arrived fast and was easy to attach to my home defense gun. It's also easy to operate and durable. Just as I expected it would be.

Never in my life did I think I would buy a two hundred dollar flashlight.  But I did. And I love it.  What a fun toy! Well, it's not a toy, but I get so much pleasure out of it that it might as well be one.

What do you get for an electronics junkie who has everything? You might consider getting this flashlight.  It has the highest light power for the smallest flashlight body that I've seen.

It has two light settings which I have termed medium and awesome:

  The "Medium" throws a beam of 15 lumens for 47 hours.

  The "Awesome" throws a beam of 200 lumens for 2 hours.

The light turns on two ways -one is the button on the back.  It is not a "click on/click off" button that you might be used to.  It is a "push in and the light turns on, and take your finger off of the back and the light turns off" button.  Push it in halfway and the medium beam comes on and push it in all the way and the awesome beam turns on.  Let go and it goes dark immediately.  At first I thought, well, that is interesting, but what if I want it to stay on permanently? No worries -it has a second method of turning the light on -just twist the end like a "mag-lite" and after a full twist the medium beam comes on, and after another half twist the awesome beam comes on.  Now it'll stay on as long as you like.

Unlike most of the cheaper LED lights that I've bought in the past, this light is very high quality -it is as solid as a brick and is made fully of anodized aluminum -no cheap plastic here! It is no surprise that you often hear the words "professional", and "tactical" when reading about this light.  These Surefire lights are often used by military, hunters, aviators, and law enforcement.  It is the type of light you see on TV detective shows all the time, where the main character holds the light up and pushes the button on the back with a thumb, illuminating the darkest areas in whatever scene they are in.  It is the kind of light which I would feel safe having while walking at night, because if I shone this in someone's eyes it would definitely blind them.

Speaking of which, this light is basically the same as the self defense flashlight that Surefire sells, with two main differences: First, the self defense flashlight's medium beam is actual a low beam -it only puts out 5 lumens versus this flashlight's 15 lumens.  5 lumens is probably fine, but I find 15 lumens to be perfect for most tasks that I really need a flashlight for.  And second, the self defense flashlight has longer crenellations on the end of the flashlight -which means it would imprint some nasty bumps on someone's forehead if you poked them with it.  Though, I would rather blind someone and take off than get into a nasty situation, so I chose the higher lumened light at the lower setting, and I am very happy with that decision.

This is the perfect light to take out with you walking at night, as it will fit perfectly in a pocket, and give you a measure of comfort knowing that you'll be able to see really far away when you need to, or to blind someone or scare them if they begin stalking or attacking you.

The Surefire brand is made in America and excepting the batteries and the LED, if you register the flashlight there is a lifetime warranty.

It also comes with a lanyard so if you are doing something where you don't have easy access to your pockets, you can just hang the light from your neck.  (The lanyard, by the way, is a "break-away" lanyard.  If you get it caught on something, and if you pull hard enough, the lanyard will break away -to prevent choking- and it is a simple activity to get it hooked back up again.)

This light uses two 3 volt lithium batteries so you might want to buy a box of them for backup.  And, these lithium batteries last for 10 years.  (Consider also purchasing the Surefire brand of batteries.  I haven't used them long enough to vouch for them, but other reviewers seem to really think they are of a higher quality than some of the generic lithium battery brands.)

By the way, you can also buy red and blue lens covers, if you wanted to change the white beam to a red or blue beam.  I don't have them but I imagine they would be very useful in night vision situations.

And, yes, the flashlight does come with batteries already installed.  You don't need to buy additional batteries to get started.

Love this light.  Can't wait for a noise outside so I can take out my trusty Surefire and blind whatever's out there!
summary: If you can afford it, an absolutely wonderful light

I love this drill set. It's got everything I need for fix-its around the apartment, except a storage case. It's compact and replaces a bulkier Black & Decker XD1200K that I owned for several years. It's handy to keep in my utility closet. I used it just last week to fix a little drawer stand in my kitchen. One of the handles had become lost, so it couldn't be easily pulled out. I decided to replace both of them with a Amerock TEN53005-G10 Door Knob, Satin Nickel, 1-1/4-Inch, 10-Pack. After drilling a hole in each drawer and screwing in the knob, the stand was useful again. I purchased this drill back in December. It either came partially charged, or I charged it once. 8 months later, the batteries are still good! I would say energy retention is outstanding! Lithium-ion exhibits low self-discharge compared to NiCad and stores energy for much longer. The keyless universal chuck means it can take drill bits of other sizes that came with other drills in my tool box. The back of the drill also has a notch for holding a second head. This is useful when changing between 2 frequently used bits. Overall, a very happy buy. It's a high-quality drill and handy to have around the house for small repairs and drilling. I only wish this set came with a carrying case for keeping all the parts together. If you need a case, consider Black & Decker BDC120VA100 20-Volt MAX Lithium-Ion Drill Kit with 100 Accessories.
summary: Everything I need for apartment fix-its, except a carrying case.

The slider on top used to open and close the blade is **exactly** in the place where I have placed my index finger for balance, control and force for decades while using any utility knife.

The pink paint wears off very easily and in my case, upon first contact with cardboard. I use these knives to cut up boxes and saw pink stripes on the cardboard...yup, down to white on the knife. Not a huuuuge deal, but a tool shouldn't look like it's been used for years when it's only been 30 minutes cutting cardboard.

Pro: it's pink color
Pro: holds extra blades
Pro: it came with extra blades! - yay, that's cool!
Pro: it holds razor blades like any other utility knife

I like that it's pink because it's easily identifiable.
Just because it's pink, doesn't mean it should be any less stout than any other burlyman utility knives.  I thought I'd be buying a utility knife that's only difference was in color.

I'll give the company another try on another tool at another time because I KNOW they're trying to provide a quality product.  :)

reviewText: prefect works great

I've had this machine a year now. Arrived with no problems. Checked tolerances on all aspects and all was okay. Start with the fact that band saws are cantankerous machines -- need a lot of TLC. If you are not familiar with them, beware that it takes time to learn how to set it up right. That said, this machine is an antique and belongs in a museum as they haven't improved a thing in 50 years. OTOH, it is amazing that this could be sold for around $1,000, so that is my perspective. This is the best of the low end machines, fine for hobbyists but not so fine for pros.

Wheels are balanced and track well. Note that vibration is usually the result of poor set up. After six months of learning how to tune it right, mine now runs perfectly smooth. Cheap blades and bad guide adjustment will make a terrible noise and vibration. I'd take the vibration complaints with a grain of salt. The problem is likely the operator and not the machine. I still use the old steel blocks that work well once you figure out how to adjust them properly.

On the postive side, all components are heavy duty stamped steel and cast iron. My machine got knocked over with a horrible crash onto concrete floor and suffered only minor damage to motor housing. The mobile base is nice, but makes it more likely to fall over.

A major negative are the lower guide controls that have "pencil" knobs and require the use of pliers to adjust them because they are very stiff. I haven't noticed other low end machines with anything better. The Jet seems an exact copy.

The blade guides are crummy but serviceable. Not sure ball bearing guides are worth the cost. Once I got used to adjusting them, it's not a big deal. You can spend a lot of money upgrading with aftermarket parts but by the time you're done you might just as well have bought a better saw from the get go.

My tension adjuster crapped out after 6 months. The standard threads couldn't handle the stress. I bought the machine wheel upgrade from Highland Hardware which is a 6" wheel (not a finger-breaking 2" knob) with Acme threads. I highly recommend it. Worth every penny of $60. I also bought the Kreg fence which, with these two items makes it a decent machine at additional cost of about $200.00. Another $200 for bearing guides and this'd be a fine machine. It's probably no coincidence that all the negatives are upgradable!!!

Set up right, it performs reasonably well. I routinely saw 1/16 x 6" wide veneers accurately with little strain on the motor. Using the right feed rate and sharp blades is critical. If you buy this machine be prepared to spend some time learning to adjust and use it right and it will perform well for you. If you think you can just start jamming pieces of wood thru it without knowledge, you'll be disappointed and end up writing nasty reviews.

reviewText: The LUCKLed rechargeable flood light weighs in at 1 lb 13 oz. There are no assembly instructions included, but it is easy to figure out. You remove the screw in the base and then put the bracket from the lamp over the screw hole, and screw the screw back in. It allows 360 movement on the base and a little more than 90 tilt up/down. There are 20 LED white lights that have two modes low and bright. One press on the power button in the back left turns it on low and another press turns it to high. You can see in the video that it does a nice job of illuminating your target. The right power button turns on a flashing red/blue light combination. This color combination is odd as I thought those colors were reserved for law enforcement. They are not very bright, but could be useful if your bar broke down and you wanted to alert other motorists. You can press both buttons and have all 24 LEDS on at the same time. There are two USB charging ports in the back of the lamp that can be used to top off any of your devices if they are running low on electrons. The ports are covered by a flimsy green plastic flap. The charging port is also located here. There are no battery indicators on the lamp. You know when it is charged as the red light on the charger goes from red to green. I was concerned with something I read in the manual. It says not to charge the light for over 24 hours. Does this mean that it will overheat? Makes me a little nervous. I see myself leaving this in the trunk of my car for emergencies. The rubber handle on the top makes it easy to carry and the rubber feet on the bottom help to keep it in place. The price is also reasonable. Disclaimer: Product sample provided for free or discounted for an honest unbiased review with no means of payment or incentives offered in exchange.

First, this is a GREAT value when it's less than a dollar!  Keep an eye on it, as the price seems to fluctuate a lot.
I use these primarily as kids toys - my toddlers love them for scooping snow, splashing in mud puddles, etc.  They're light enough, and the edges aren't sharp, so I don't mind them playing with these.
But even though this is a plastic trowel, it can absolutely be used as a serious tool.  It wouldn't stand up to heavy use in compacted soils, but then again, most inexpensive metal trowels don't either.  I've used too many really cheap trowels where the metal just bends - these "composite" tools are definitely stronger than many of those.  If you're potting plants in soil from a bag, or if you're working in any sort of plowed/tilled garden, this trowel will work just fine.  And if you can get it for less than a buck, why not.
My only hesitation is that they might start to become brittle if they're left out in the sun for a long time - this would probably take years, as mine are showing NO signs of weakening after a year.  But at least they won't rust!
summary: Useful in potting mix or loose soil, or as a (slightly safer) toy for kids too young for metal trowels

reviewText:
I heard some people talking about a projector like this, and how much it helped their baby sleep at night.  I figured if it worked at all, it would be worth every penny.  It is.

The lights are very soothing, and can be adjusted almost any way you want.  All colors, some colors, or one color; moving and changing or still; constant colors or some fading in or out.  The ability to tilt it over makes it much more versatile, since it can be put at the edge of the room and still fill the entire ceiling (note that the tilting mechanism enables it to tilt towards the controls on the base, not in other directions - some people seemed to have a little trouble figuring out which way it went).  The overall design is very aesthetically pleasing, and will fit almost any dcor.  The materials seem to be pretty good quality.

The only two things I might consider changing aren't really negatives at all, but I feel they should be mentioned.  The sounds that come with this aren't quite as soothing as I would prefer for a nursery (or myself, really) - they're nature sounds, but most of them do have a sudden, loud sound (bird calling or something similar) every once in a while.  But if you have a baby and don't already have an app like Relax Melodies to use on your phone instead, you're missing out.  I'd also love to see a battery built in so that the projector can more easily be moved from one room to another, depending on where it's needed at the moment.  Our plug is behind a piece of furniture, but we can easily fix that problem with a  $1 extension cord.  I guess a battery would also drive the price up $5-10, which may put this item out of the reach of some parents who could really use it.  And of course, the instructions are in broken English, but that's exactly what I expected.  This thing is completely self-explanatory anyway.

I do love the remote, and the ability to control it from a distance.  If your fussy baby has just fallen asleep on you, you know you're not going to be getting up to change it manually anytime soon.  I also really like the timer feature, which can be useful for all kinds of things.  Save energy by not running it overnight, or turn off the sound so that your baby doesn't become dependent on noise to sleep.  Or maybe the best one - use the 8 hour timer for toddlers, to teach them that while the light is on, it's sleeping time.  They can't get out of bed (and come wake you up) until that light goes off.  It's called "OK to wake", and it's becoming a very popular thing to train for.  Most of the devices that support this are fairly expensive.  Who knew this thing would have this ability at least partially built in?

I assume that because this is a low end stapler that maybe a higher end electric stapler could be a better chose than a mechanical stapler

reviewText: It does cut 2" PVC pipe with room to spare. But a couple tips. First the blade while not razor thin (that would probably break anyway) it does have a slight double sided bevel and gets harder to turn as the walls of the bevel on either side of the blade run into thicker and thicker walls of cut PVC pipe on either side. Friction goes up and it simply makes sense it gets harder and harder to turn. Lessening the depth for each go around does not lessen the increase in friction. Holding the pipe still becomes very hard without a vise. Second (you can) grab a PVC right angle or other type of end piece and wedge it to the bottom without glue or cement. The friction of a slightly imperfectly aligned end piece wedged against the walls of a large pipe makes an excellent "lever" to counter the torque caused by the cutting blade in very cramped and awkward compartments, like in a crawl space. I'm a small guy and was able to wedge the right angle PVC fitting between my boots while I perfectly cut a section of pipe about as long as my torso. Also the roller pin that holds the blade in the center fork is held in place by a cotter pin or rotating ring washer that fits in a groove around the axis of the roller pin. This can pop out if the fork or the blade is torqued or twisted in the wrong way. In tight quarters this is very possible.. in the near dark almost a certainty. The cut will still be level and clean, but those last few millimeters the blade has the most frictional torque twisting it in the groove its cutting. Smaller pipe than near its maximum capacity would probably be a lot easier to cut.

I love general finishes products.  The only reason why I gave this 4 stars is because I am just not a huge fan of gel coats.  They tend to sit on top of the wood instead of being absorbed into the wood like a nice waterborne stain.  So if you just so happen to have to do a little touch up sanding after you have stained that you may have missed in the prepping process.  You will be screwed as gel coats are very easy to sand through even with light sanding with something like a 320 grit.  Though these gel coats have their advantages.  As they don't absorb into the wood as much they are much less prone to blotching.  So they are great for blotch prone woods.  They also just look fantastic when applied properly.  I used this gel stain because I needed a dark rich brown to finish a table top I was working on.  The java color fits the bill perfectly.  It is the color of dark roast coffee with out concealing all the beautiful wood grain, and it just comes to life and jumps out at you when you put a nice coat of poly on it.

The headband adjusts and stays at the size you leave it at. I have a ginormous head and this still fit.

I consider the lanyard to be integral and when not in immediate use, the flashlight goes around the neck.  It feels so much better and is much easier to twist the cap in your palm or your fingertips, depending on how you hold it, to turn it on and off.

I needed this to plane a few new interior doors I installed.  Had never really used a planer (powered or otherwise) before, but thought I'd give it a try versus the mess created by using a belt-sander or similar.  Plus, at less than $60, if it worked reasonably well, how could I go wrong?

Even though this is a tool I'm only likely to use rarely, I have to admit, it really does work well for its purpose.  I'm not a carpenter or anything, just a homeowner DIY-type who likes to try to do things myself versus always paying someone else to do it for me.  Truthfully, sometimes I'm more successful than others.  I'd "planed" sticking or miss-aligned doors in the past using a belt-sander.  That method worked okay, but made a mess and it was easy to "over-sand". So I got the Ryobi planer and gave it a shot. Wow! I can't speak as to how this Ryobi compares to other powered planers, but it sure impressed me! It took down the doors no problem.  The first door I did I just used the included debris bag.  It did an "okay" job, but still alot of dust was released into the workspace. The next couple of doors I did, I just inserted my shop-vac hose (smaller shop-vac) into the planer's blow-out port I was using, turned on the shop-vac and started planing. That worked like a charm!  Almost no dust or debris got away from the tool and shop-vac.

The planer seemed to be plenty powerful for my needs. It has decent "heft" to it. It comes with a spare set of blades (the installed ones and the included extra set are both reversible, so they should last for quite awhile), the dust/debris bag and the metal guides. For a rookie at planing, I am very impressed with the tool and at the price I got it, would definitely recommend it. My only gripe is that the unit I received had a lot of sawdust on the tool and the interior of its case.  Now I recognize that I am buying a "reconditioned" tool, but is it too much to ask that the tool and its case be vacuumed off a bit when it is in the reconditioning (whatever that means......) process?  10 seconds with a shop-vac by the seller and that is one gripe I wouldn't have had!!!!
summary: Casual User----Worked Great! Wish I'd bought a planer years ago....

reviewText:
When I buy something like a miter saw, I buy for long term.  I came across this saw at the home center that came with the heavy duty Miter saw stand.  It came with the two brackets to mount to quick mount the saw.  $200 stand for free.  Awesome!  I did all the standard straight cuts stacking outdoor landscape lumber as high as it would fit.  Two high, two wide was enough for me to risk and it sliced right through, sliding all the way up to 16".  Amazing.  I bought over my needs for a reason.  I was repairing my bench seat for the dining room and this saw has a depth stop that allowed me to fine tune like a table saw so that I could mimic dado cuts.  I cut a 1x1 down to 9/16" by 5/16" that was " long of a peg on each side.  After I made the marks, just do the quick blade depth adjustment and I was sawing.  It has really inspired my wood working for 2014.  It cuts all the way to 55* on each side.  Has quick stops for 22.5 and 38 something degrees.  I know crown molding uses one of them.  This saw can do all that any miter out there can do.

It has a saw dust catch bag.  My garage would probably look better if I used it or a vac system.
There is also an adjustable clamp that mounts to the saw to help reduce losing fingers.
The LED is an awesome upgrade from nothing and it is better than a laser bc if a laser isn't set up right your line isn't right.  This shadows the blade and it works perfect to setup your cut.  Even high noon day light you can see the shadow.

I love it and it per sways me to Dewalt with everything else.
summary: Owned for a year and I'm still learning new things!!!!

reviewText: The KitchenAid Disposal we had was 27 years old and working just fine, but we had new granite countertops installed so we upgraded to this new disposal.  It is just great!!  So quiet!  So happy with it and it should run for another 27 years or more!!  Thanks KitchenAid!!

These fit our bathroom light fixtures perfectly. 12 bulbs for 15 bucks is a great deal. Of course that will depend on if they last a decent length of time. They came whole, none were broken. There are 2 to a sealed pack and all 6 packs were packaged well for shipping. Great deal!

As some other reviewers have noted, using this in a hanging lamp fixture (bulb BELOW the module) causes the module to heat and lose the ability to be controlled by X-10 sources. A 100w bulb in the thing for 60 seconds rendered mine uncontrollable. I pulled the 100w and replaced it with a 25w and I've been able to leave it on for at least 5 min and not lose controllability. Contrary to the documents, it does seem to work with a <40w bulb.

It is NOT DIMMABLE. That seems like a fabulous feature of the older and no longer available LM20 modules. Those older 20s were a lot more robust. I wish they were still available. What could possibly be a good reason for removing the dimmable feature? That seems like the coolest part of all this remote control voodoo.

X-10 seems to flaunt the "no dial setting required" as some kind of feature. I don't see that as a feature in the least. Turning two simple dials with a screwdriver was certainly not a challenge. It's a lot more work to program the silly thing using the lamp and controller plugged into the same outlet method that is now required.

Overall it's a step backwards in features, reliability and versatility. I'm using only because, as far as I can tell, it's the only screw in lamp module still available.
summary: High Heat in Hanging Lamps Causes Module Failure

I was a little worried about ordering this chandelier.  I found one I loved at ZGallerie for $500 and was sad that I couldn't get it.  It had a beautiful glass orb hanging from it that I really loved.  Whenever I find something in a store that I love but don't want to pay an arm and a leg for, I turn to Amazon.  I followed the directions using the zip ties to put the rings together and it was very easy to put together.  The chain was too short for the length I wanted my orb to hang.  I really like the look of down-rods and decided to buy a down-rod instead of a longer chain.  I looked online and they were all expensive.  I went to Lowe's and all they sold were ceiling fan down-rods.  I wanted a thin rod like the orb itself.  I discovered a mini pendant light that came with an adjustable rod up to 69.57 inches.  It was only $20 and perfect for my vaulted ceilings.  For $20 I could justify buying it for parts!  I drilled a hole in the bottom of the rod and hooked two large key rings through it so that I could attach the orb to it's new rod.  I painted the key rings with some oil rubbed bronze paint I had on hand so that everything matched.  My hubs used the canopy from the pendant so the the rod would connect easily and the wiring was just like any light.  I also purchased a crystal off Amazon to bling up my chandelier.  I tied it on with fishing line.  I am so happy with my chandelier, I actually like it better than the $500 ZGallerie Orb.  It is worth every penny, you will not be disappointed!

I felt like I was at a haunted house or a rave party and NOT in a good/fun way.  I was never able to use the dimmer switch until I got these and what a JOY!  I don't know how long they'll be around, or if they're still making them, but until I can't get them anymore, these are the only light bulbs I will buy.  The light is a little softer. Update: Jan. 31, 2013. If I could give this an extra star for customer service, I would. While trying to redirect the light last week, I slipped, pulled the front off, and broke the battery cover. It seems that the battery cover is very important: the light doesn't work without it. I wrote to Mr Beams, and they said that they would replace the whole unit at no charge, and today - 4 days later - I received the new unit. It works like a charm, and I'm grateful for the excellent customer service that they provided. Btw, it's been two months, and they haven't skipped a beat or beam as the case may be. They're working fine, and the light is bright enough to cover the doors and immediate walkways.

****

I got the two MB360s LED Spotlight Motion Sensors so that I didn't have to leave front and back lights on when we were gone for a day, and then when we got home, these would light up the doors (and locks) and, if necessary, I could turn on the lights from the garage. I've never thought of using these before, but recently our little cul de sac has had three new families move in and they're evidently saving on their electric bills.

And then there was the safety factor: If there are intruders - and I include raccoons, opossums, and once even a wayward tiger that was reported by our neighborhood watch (it was, not quite as I expected - but close - the fattest cat in the neighborhood: didn't even have stripes!) - when these lights go off, the prism that magnifies the light does quite a job. It lights up half of the outside of our house and all the nooks and crannies that are out there.

I was concerned about wearing out 4 D Cell batteries every few weeks because as a motion sensor, they might go off in the daytime. But these are set to go off only when there is little light between sunset and sunrise.

I know that some have said that these are easily installed. Well, charge your electric drill because each comes with two 3.5-inch very thin screws per light. My drill was dead as a doornail, and the wood that I was using has been "cured" by 40 years of paint and sun-baked. It took 30 minutes for the first one to screw it in by hand. When my brain had enough power to have a light bulb go off, I just waited for the drill/screwdriver to charge. Still not so easy since they really are VERY thin screws.

So far, they're working fine. We haven't had a raccoon or possum in over 24 hours! No burglars either unless you consider Sydney, our neighborhood squirrel, the biggest thief of the bunch. (But kudos for neatness Sydney.)

ew
summary: Bright Spot Can Be Directed Where You Need It ... Or Defensively

*Disclosure: I was contacted by a rep for SleekLighting and provided a free sample for the purposes of giving my thoughts on it.*

Cool and bright!  LEDs, and CFL, home lighting is the way most of us are going in order to reduce our power bills.  Sleeklighting brings to the table these chandelier bulbs, which will fit a variety of lighting solutions, but not all.  As is common, the LED bulb is taller and fatter than the standard incandescent bulb of the same type.  Roughly 3/4" taller and 1/4" wider.  This is something to consider, as the extra size may not fit your need.  Also, this product *IS NOT DIMMABLE*.  LEDs operate differently than CFL or incandescent bulbs, such that reducing the voltage to them does not cause them to dim, which is how the majority of dimmer switches work. LEDs need the supplied current to vary, rather than voltage.

Also unlike CFL or incandescent bulbs, LEDs produce focus light beams, whereas the others radiate light in every direction.  To get around this, the Sleeklighting bulb is ringed with LEDs all the way around the primary shaft, as well as at top of the shaft.  It does a pretty good job of spreading the light around, but I think the lack of a covering to further diffuse the light is problematic. The diffusing cuts down the overall brightness and sharpness of the light while also spreading it about.  Given that these bulbs are for chandeliers, the light being produced is in my opinion at bit too bright and sharp for that use.  The exception being if the chandelier in question is mounted high up, like on a vaulted ceiling, which will tone down the lighting as it travels and bounces off surfaces.  A group of these, undimmed, in a standard household chandelier which is often 6' high, may be too intense.  No intimate dinner with these bad boys!  They may be too intense for small beside lamps as well, even with a shade.

I do think this is a great product, but it will take some time to see just how long it will last.  In theory, unless plugged into a dimmer, they should last a good long time, making the investment on them well worth it.

This was a replacement for an old-school contractor's grade lock on our front door (our house is about ten years old and we're going through the process of updating fixtures a little at a time). This is a great upgrade from a traditional key-only lock. It was easy to install and configure, and using it has been very simple. It feels a little strange at first, trusting your house to a code instead of a key (which is sort of crazy because everything is key-pad locked these days...) but it's been a great change for our family. We have a ten year old who sometimes loses her key in the dark recesses of her school backpack, and this enables her to get right into the house when she's dropped off from carpool without having to wait for us to come answer the door. I use a cane when I walk (Spina Bifida), so I don't have to juggle everything I'm carrying to be able to pull out the keys and get in- I can just tap the buttons. My husband can bring the groceries up to the door and get into the house without having to drop everything and unlock the door.

My only wish was that it was smart-phone syncable, but that's next on our wish-list.

This is a great replacement/upgrade for a contractor's lock, or a great first entry into the world of electronic locks. Highly recommended.

If you're looking for a workhorse knife under 20 dollars, I can't think of anything that beats the Drifter. It gets so many things right - grippy handle, functional thumb studs, smooth opening, solid lockup, nested liners, well-centered blade, relatively large blade/handle ratio, and better edge retention than the 420HC blades typically sold at this price. And it just looks cool and more expensive than it is. The only minor gripes with this knife is that the clip is very stiff and can't be repositioned to the other corners, and that the liners aren't drilled. . This recessed LED light requires an already-installed ceiling can. Do you want a $25 to $30 kit like this instead of a BR30 LED reflector bulb? Maybe you like the clean look. Maybe you don't already have the $9 trim kit that's used with regular bulbs. Or you like the sealed-off aspect of these kits...the room is better sealed against spiders, fiberglass, and warm/cool air flow. On the other hand, these are twice the price, a little less efficient, the amount of recess is not adjustable, and there are fewer choices (brightness, light color, spot vs flood, etc.) If you go with this style, there's plenty of competition, and prices are headed down. Today's 4-star bulb might be next month's overpriced inferior bulb. So, check around for the best specs, price, and light quality. Right now, this bulb is in the running. I love competition with the Power tool companies. It means that the tools just keep getting better. I love my mag 77 saws but they are no longer the best you can buy. Dewalt must have cut into the sales of Skils wormdrive market with their innovative framers saw. I like some of the features on it but still prefer the Skilsaw for its torque and durability. Skil and Bosch must have been listening to their customers because this new (Old) saw is much better than the original 77 or the Mag 77. The shoe is stiffer now. The power is a little better, not that it was lacking before. The hook is nice. Thanks Dewalt. The best thing though is the easier to use guard. It really works better. This truly is the best saw money can buy. It will not only outlast everything else on the market, it will make you smile every time you use it.

We install speakers and home automation, so we go thru a lot of these drills.  The blue color is a nice touch, it makes them look more professional to clients who see them. The primary picture in the description is a little deceptive, as you only see 5-6" of the drill, but they are a full 72" Please note that I received these at a discount in exchange for an honest and unbiased review. Opinions are entirely my own. I hope this review is helpful for you!

This is one cool downspout extender!  It rotates full 180 degrees, bends up / down, and is as rugged as advertised.  One I used on a bank near the SW corner of the house, and I neatly buried the flat portion below the grass line, then I embedded a 16-inch paver at the end to displace the end flow.  A little creative landscaping, and your downspouts can be greatly improved.  On the other side, I used the add-on extenders above ground to get the water further away from the foundation.

Put two on my sisters' home - they had the smaller downspouts, but no problem as the adapters are included.  Embedded pavers at the end of the flow.

You can do surgery with this saw.  We use it primarily for fine finish carpentry and crown molding work, etc.  Chose this saw over the sliding model because you can work with larger crown using the crown stops and we felt the accuracy would be better than the sliding model.  Can't speak for the sliding model but cutting precision on this model, once we upgraded to a decent blade, simply couldn't be improved on.  Those that can only afford a single miter saw and want all the bells and whistles may prefer the sliding model but I'd recommend this one over the slider for those who want perfection in their cuts.

Customer Service is worthless. I called about a month ago to get details on the product and make sure I would have support when I began the application. I ended up believing  there would be support and ordered Durbak. Every call was placed Mon-Fri during business hours. My first call it went to voicemail which should have answered my question about the support. Eventually He returned my call and gave a bunch of excuses why they didn't answer the phone. Second call about roughing up the surface when to voicemail and eventually returned the call 4 hours later. The last call was made 10 min before I was ready to pop the lid, and again right to voice mail. So I called Herculiner and they answered my question so I could begin my project.  Herculiner and Durbak are made in the same factory and different labels are put on them. Don't wast your time with Durbak, You won't get the support you need and it's more expensive. The results of Herculiner was amazing, and you'll get the support you need.  The frustration of working with Durbak ins't worth it. Same product, more expensive, customer service is worthless.
summary: Go with Herculiner, same stuff, different name, much cheaper.

Believe all the great reviews.  The tester works as advertised, finds the general area of the leak and then you adjust the sensitivity again until you pinpoint the exact spot.  The "tip light" is invaluable in dark areas, as where I found a propane leak today that a plumber wanted more than the price of this unit to find for me.  Maybe I'll never need it again, but it has already paid for itself, so I'm happy.  The tester is well made, durable and has a great soft sleeve that fits it perfectly to protect it from being banged around.

To the reviewer who had trouble with the adjustment, maybe you didn't fully read the instructions?  It does take several adjustments to the sensitivity to find the exact spot of the leak, but the adjustments are easy to do.

reviewText: well made holding up several months later

About a year and a half ago, I bought two of these Comfort seats.  Installation was unbelievably easy--the bolts tightened up right away and stayed tight. Fit was perfect.  Wood finish was excellent to begin with and has remained that way.  Stainless screws are the right material for this application.  The chrome has tarnished a bit over time, but it cleaned up nicely with Nevr-Dull metal polish.  In sum, the seats look about as good now as they did when they came out of the box.

Two minor problems.  First, the hardware that came with the seats was not the same as illustrated in the instructions.  The manufacturer's website has the same obsolete instructions.  That leaves the question of how to sequence the washers.  Please see Kris M.'s accompanying Amazon.com review for the answer.

Second, after a year and a half, one of the nylon nuts cracked and dropped off.  I was able to quickly improvise a repair using a hex nut.  Then I emailed the manufacturer about the broken nylon nut.  Got an immediate and courteous response that a replacement part would be shipped the same day.  It arrived two days later.  I appreciate that the manufacturer's customer service is on a par with the high quality of the product.  With the OEM part the seat is as good as new.

In sum, these toilet seats are highly recommended.  It seems to me that the people who put so much thought and quality into this product would deserve the Nobel Prize for Toilet Seats if there were such a thing.

Follow-up, 2016. The Comfort seats I purchased over five years ago are still going strong.  The chrome has tarnished, but otherwise the seats are as good as new.
